+Great music
+Well done combat interaction
There are only a couple issues I've run across while playing.
-The level up system doesn't show how your stuff is getting better in terms of numbers, you have to just be able to notice the very slight increases in performance.
-Enemies can start their attack animations BEFORE they spawn in, leading to times you will take unavoidable dmg
-The range of enemy attacks is deceptive because they extend slightly beyond the animation. If you dodge as an attack is coming down you will still get hit. Instead you need to wait till just before the attack hits.

151117849.review:
I dumped like 8 hours into this on the steam deck. I cannot get the files to sync at all. It is very frustrating...

Anyway, this game is fine. Everything is above average but I just don't feel like it was great. I see  many people saying it will be a memorable game for them and I can't really imagine why other than a short, slightly unique story.

Combat is fine. Fluid enough but not going to be remembered for just that. You got your rolls, your swings and your awkward ranged that you won't be able to weave into the fights too often. PS you can hit back magic bolts at enemies.

The level up process is just a standard kill things to get souls (lol 1 soul bullshit things mostly...) or you pick up orbs worth literally 100x the amount of killing an enemy. That won't be changed at this point in the game's life but it is a joke in my opinion. These souls will let you level up one of your four or five stats. Roll faster, swing faster, swing further and cast ranged faster. Standard upgrades.

Now there are a few enemies worth 10 and even fewer worth 50 however combat versus them is boring. Maybe that's where the souls like comparison comes in from some people. You swing once, maybe twice, then you roll away. Then repeat. Not even mildly challenging. Just time consuming.

This game needs a fucking map too. Metroidvania style games usually have a map. No matter how crude it is.

Speaking of dedicated buttons, ranged attacks can usually be thrown without having to aim. This rewards people who are good at twin sticks if they can tell where your character is aiming. This game does NOT allow you to do that. You have to stop and aim with LT then shoot with B ( or whatever your controller does). 

The backtracking is fucking brutal. I am all for having to backtrack a little bit in some games but holy hell, there are so many small things you have to backtrack for to finish up this game that I don't even care my steam deck isn't syncing to my main computer for me to finish. I don't want to go back to every world (there's only like 3 and they are well) to just get a few level ups or collectibles, but some people might. I'm at like 76% complete without doubling back for stuff.

Story is good. Unique enough but not a hall of fame contender. Art is gorgeous too but I've seen this style plenty before, too.

All in all, I paid like $8 for this and played it on vacation when one of our hiking days got rained out. I do not regret this and think you will get enough enjoyment out of it in the 8-10 hours it takes.

150541706.review:
Got this game free as a PS5 Plus member and bought it on sale for Steam.

Death's Door is comedic, brilliant, atmospheric, and very fun.

The goofiness of playing a crow wielding a giant sword, shooting arrows and throwing bombs at a large, jumping toad while he smashes the place is just brilliant and I loved it.

The soundtrack is excellent.  Loved all the fitting details in melody and chord modulations.

Wonderfully captivating cinematics.

The gameplay in Death's Door was immediately appealing to me as someone who has played through the timeless masterpiece Bloodborne half a dozen times.

The dialogues were clever, thoughtful and rewarding.  Completing the game with a 100%-rating to unlock the true ending was absolutely worth it.  I am a sucker for true endings.

I have three issues with the game. 
It does not feature a mini-map, so you may get lost trying to earn that cool 100%.  
No New Game Plus, so your fun with the purple sword is limited.
We could also use some silly costumes or head pieces for the crow, or all the crows, simply because!

Thanks for a great game.

149793347.review:
Death's Door knows what it is, and is good at it, but it could be a bit more - that goes for almost all areas of the game, aside from the world beautiful and varying world, and the great somber soundtrack. It works perfectly on Steam Deck as well.

The game consists of traveling to different areas and using one of five weapons and four abilities that you slowly unlock to find secrets, defeat enemies and open new paths. In classic metroidvania style, some areas can only be accessed or opened with an ability you get later. Traveling between areas is fast and easy thanks to a hub area, so you constantly discover new things. The story fits the mood of the game and the artstyle in general is fantastic, making the game almost feel like a miniature playset unfolding before you.

While the game does not overstay it's welcome and is only about 9-13 hours long, depending on how much you want to get 100 %, it does feel a bit lacking in some aspects. Combat is generally pretty easy as enemy patterns are predictable and there are only a handful of them for most of the game. Exploration via abilities is cool, but to get 100 %, you need to do a lot of backtracking and find some items that there is no hint for if you missed them, particularly the seeds and shiny things. That means that, if you miss something, you have to travel every area again to find a spot you may have missed, which can be frustrating (unless you use a guide of course). 

Movement also feels a bit floaty and "drunk" at times - I found myself falling off of tight pathways a lot when just trying to move straight. The game has an upgrade system using souls from enemies or pickups, but getting all stats to max is impossible in one playthrough without excessive grinding (I was about 4000 souls short even with a lot of exploration), so focus on the stats you prefer.

Overall, though, those are nitpicks. The game works, is fun for the most part, and has a fantastic soundtrack and gorgeous presentation. If you like this style of game, Death's door is definitely worth playing through.

149661277.review:
A good game that wears its inspirations on its sleeve and still manages to stand out from them, even if it can't quite earn a seat at the big boys' table.

Death's Door is an adventure game that takes inspiration from Dark Souls, Studio Ghibli, and, more than anything, Zelda, specifically 2D Zelda games such as A Link to the Past or its sequel, A Link Between Worlds. Gameplay consists primarily of exploring large and often complex areas that function effectively like 2D Zelda dungeons. Having omitted an overworld in the traditional sense, Death's Door's developers have crafted roughly 10 dungeons that lead into one another, some paired together such as the Estate of the Urn Witch and the Furnace Observation Rooms to create the sense of one large and true dungeon, but the lack of any separation between overworld and dungeon as there is in Zelda highlights that the entire world (with the exception of its hub location) functions as a series of dungeons.

By creating a vast series of Zelda dungeons, Acid Nerve place a lot of whether the game works or not on to its level design, and fortunately they deliver on that promise, the isometric view allowing for more depth than a traditional Zelda dungeon and intricate looping locations that are a joy to explore. Some are populated with enemies, creating a sense of fast paced action, others with puzzles such as lighting lanterns, hitting switches, collecting keys, and other staples of the Zelda series. Importantly, both work, aided by the game's strong art direction and charming visuals. Mansions, flooded ruins, factories, each has a real sense of place.

And at the end of the 'partnered' dungeons is a boss to fight, requiring understanding of your basic moveset and the boss' attacks. While by no means a scratch on the kind of boss you would expect to fight in a more combat oriented game such as Devil May Cry or even more recent Zelda titles such as Breath of the Wild, these are fun encounters that perfectly encapsulate the spirit of old Zelda bosses without copying their formulaic approach to items, and their designs match the world perfectly.

I also want to take a quick moment to acknowledge the incredibly creative and intelligent approach to health and checkpoints in Death's Door. In the years since Dark Souls, many games attempting a similar style of adventure have mimicked the estus flasks system, but Death's Door has come up with a new approach. Scattered around the world in places where a checkpoint would be useful are big green pots, and scattered around in little hiding places are seeds, single use consumable items. Planting a seed in one of these big pots causes a plant to grow that can be eaten to restore all your health, but the catch is that plant will not regrow unless you die. Healing is limited to these specific spots, and every potential checkpoint prompts a choice based on the amount of seeds you have, how far into an area you are, etc. It's a fantastic approach that should be commended.

Unfortunately, there are shortcomings to Death's Door, and I use the term purposefully because I don't feel that there are truly any negatives to point out, only things that could have been developed further. Firstly, the game's length. On your adventure there are only 3 giant souls that need to be collected, an admittedly paltry amount especially when compared to the most recent 2D Zelda game, 2013's A Link Between Worlds. In that game, three pendants are required to be collected only to unlock a whole other realm, with a further 7 dungeons in it, effectively the start of the real meat of the game, and A Link Between Worlds is only following in its many predecessors' footsteps. Finding 3 quest items in a Zelda game often means the main game is about to start, yet in Death's Door it means things are wrapping up.

Another shortcoming is in the game's puzzles. While fun and often unique to each area, the puzzles are on the light side in terms of challenge. By no means is this terrible, but considering the games it draws influence from, I would have hoped for some tough as nails head scratchers by the endgame.

Finally, there's no map. Again, this is not a true misstep, but given the complexity of some of the areas, a map would have been a good choice, even if only as a rough outline of some of the areas really aiming for an old-school dungeon feel.

Despite these shortcomings, Death's Door is a fantastically well made game and a fun diversion, but feels more like a starter than the main course, so I can't recommend it at full price, but if it's on sale it's well worth showing support to a two man team that managed to craft such an intricate world.

149513203.review:
Where to even start...
Death's door was a delightful experience that does so many things right.
From the excellent art style that will have you admiring landscapes and taking screenshots, to the incredible soundtrack, everything in this game reflects so much of the thought and attention that went into this absolute masterpiece.
The combat albeit a bit simplistic when looking at the weapons and skills variety, makes up for it in enemy variety and originality. Every single enemy will have their very own attacking patterns, vastly different from each other with really original twists to them. You are free to use not only the environment to your advantage but also to pivot certain enemies' attacks against each other.
The boss fights are challenging without being frustrating, it's not Hollow Knight difficulty, but it is enough to keep you engaged and paying close attention to enemy attack patterns.
The character and world design really pull you into the world as well as the story line, and although I wasn't counting on it, I ended up really enjoying the process of putting the story together bit by bit.

All in all, even though there are some pain points (the most painful one being the lack of a map, for example, which I felt sometimes caused me to miss certain hidden areas of the level and kind of discouraged me from backtracking as much as I would have had I had a map), I had such a great time with this game, the fluid and challenging combat, the whimsical characters and the absolutely lovely art style and soundtrack made it a memorable experience and one I wholeheartedly recommend to anyone

149394098.review:
Excellent action-adventure game. The basis of the gameplay draws from Zelda, but with emphasis on combat over environemental puzzles. However, the latter are still present and well-made.

You begin the game as a crow fletchling, on your first day as a grim reaper.
However, the very first job goes sideways and you have to fix it. This takes you on an adventure through  eerie, unsettling lands while feeling the heat from the bureaucrats at the office of soul-reaping.

The strongest point of Death's Door is the level design. It's incredible. Main areas are large and semi-open, with paths looping seemlessly. It makes it so the player is never lost wandering aimlessly in search of another door, while at the same time giving them the ability to explore and maintaing the illusion of a vast world.
Simiarly to Zelda, it also features more enclosed and segmental dungeon-like areas. You collect keys, battle mini-bosses , and unlock doors that eventually lead you to a big boss.

As in Zelda, you will also obtain new tools along your journey that let you access new areas. But in Death's Door, each tool also significantly changes how you will control the character: the game ups its pace constantly. It's a thrill, knowing that you are always on the verge of getting another shiny toy that will enhance your character and allow you to do even cooler things.

To sum it up, Death's Door is a fantastic game. It sucks you for an intense ride: you jump through platforms and pits, fight hordes of deadly monsters, and befriend peculiar characters on your quest to get through your first day of work.

I would call Death's Door a good game, but not a great game. 

The mechanics are solid, gameplay is responsive, but a lot of the exploring you need to do feels repetitive and without reward. 

The narrative falls a bit flat halfway through, and by the time you've invested more time to possibly earn more, you become blindsided by new information that really has no core correlation to the main plot. Explanation: [spoiler] The entire motivation of the Lord of Doors without any real involvement in the story up to that point only to be led on by the idea that this other entity, The Truth, that has had no explanation in the main game to be the main motor and cause for the entire game to move into motion [/spoiler]

I do enjoy the idea of having fixed heal points in the form of pots that you plant healing flowers into that will always respawn after you die, but will not rebloom until after reloading the area.

148385985.review:
7/10
This was quite a good game with some issues though that don't allow it to be as enjoyable as I hoped for. 
For starters the game is poorly optimized to be played on a PC. I had to do some tweaking, play it on windowed mode and have it run from the computers registry (not from the steam app hence the low number of hours displayed), just to not have it stuttering even on very low specs. 
Gameplay is fun without bringing anything new to the table from other established titles, although it seemed a bit easy for my liking. Most enemies  and bosses are easy to figure out and I can say I didn't find any boss challenging. The atmosphere is beautiful, the graphics are really well drawn and the music or the lack of it in some instances fit very well with the environment. 
My biggest issue with the game is the lack of a map. You can finish the base game without it being more than a little annoyance but if you want to finish the full game and unlock the secret ending it is extremely frustrating. Backtracking without the tools of navigating shouldn't be a thing and there is a lot of backtracking required if you want to get 100%. 
Overall I would recommend the game if you are a fan of the genre but I would advice anyone who wants to finish the whole game to search online beforehand about collectibles and so he/she can mentally or physically mark locations that will be needed to be revisited afterwards.

147590491.review:
I'm not saying this game is bad. It's fun, it's a fine game. But that's all it really is to me, fine. I'm about 50 % in of total game completion atm, and let's go down the list.
The bosses? Really nothing special.
The difficulty? Apparently some people really struggle, but to me it's super easy. I have 24 seeds that I haven't planted because I don't really need the health going through the levels.  Just don't attack when it's obviously a bad idea, stick and move a little, and use a lot of magic arrows. Being easy isn't a problem, of course though, but it's a very simple action game. 
You have a simple few-hit combo, a charge, and a hard to use dodge-roll attack, plus the magic. And all the upgrades this game gives you either stat-wise or through new magic and weapons won't radically change anything. I wish it had couple of different combos ala DMC 1 with diff timings. Or charging your weapon with diff timings does something else. Or the weapons actually changed your attack more.
You don't have any bullet-hell kind of action so your spatial awareness or positioning doesn't actually have to be that good. The game doesn't really pressure you with too many enemies. And the bosses aren't gonna be aggressive or fast like Dark Souls or Hollow-Knight (and there's only been 2 bosses so far, and the frog guy kinda just sits there and throws bombs at you.). The biggest curve-ball is that some enemies have some delayed attacks, or poor tells between their 1 and 2 hit combos.

The music is fine, but isn't the best you've heard, and the style of the game is nice, but not ground-breaking. The writing doesn't have a lot to it. Just like in terms of design, Urn Witch has a much better story than the Frog King.
And lastly, the dungeon: Most of the puzzles in this game involves finding your way to a vertical spot in a room from which you can light a torch from afar, and things like that. They aren't exactly high-tier puzzles, but I like them, keeps the flow going. The layouts are fine though, and the enemies are good.

I really wish this game at least had better movement. You spend so much of this game just dodge-rolling just like you would in 3D Zelda. Your new abilities just boil down to new barriers you can unlock now, sometimes through back-tracking. And you can't go out of order in the game either because harder areas are blocked by things you can't open yet, like not being able to bomb a cracked wall.

Really, I've had some fun with the game, it just really isn't doing anything I can be impressed by or really consider a good amount of fun. I'd recommend other, better action games, especially considering its price. Get a beat em up like Streets of Rage, maybe.

146258713.review:
Death's Door: Isometric Zelda-like Perfection

Death's Door is an absolute hidden gem of an indie game. To start with what you'd notice first, the graphics are beautiful; especially for an indie.  It has a very striking style that compliments the game very well; I always found myself wowed by the varied environments this game has you exploring. It easily stands as one of the best looking indie games I've ever played.

The gameplay doesn't slouch either, it starts of simple enough, but with the multiple weapons and spells you can acquire alongside the upgrade system it truly becomes something special. It takes that classic Zelda combat and makes it more dynamic and engaging. Throughout the game you encounter many unique enemies that compliment each other in battle; making you play your best and utilize all your tools to succeed.

Now when you aren't battling, you are exploring, and man the levels in this game are just plain satisfying to explore. They are very intricately designed with many secrets and parts that loop back on each other, not to mention new abilities allowing you to backtrack to find even more secrets and collectibles. Speaking of collectibles, while there are many that are there just for the sake of finding them, the majority are either souls for leveling, or seeds; this games healing system. There are a certain amount of pots scattered around each area, and if you have a seed in your inventory you can use it to plant a soul fruit: a full heal that respawns only once the area is reloaded (or you die). It's great because you always have the decision to press on and save your seed, or cash out for safer exploration. Thorough players are rewarded with many more seeds, allowing for more leeway in exploration. It's a great system that isn't too punishing and encourages you to explore these levels.

But what really makes this game shine are the characters and writing, all the characters are super lovable and written well. Most of the games jokes really land and it makes you much more attached to this world. I won't spoil the story but I will say it gets much deeper than I expected when I played it. Gotta give a shout out to the score, can be epic and intense, or melancholic and atmospheric, with great use of motifs, truly something special to listen to.

This is an game that will stick with you, the world, characters, exploration, and story come together to create and incredibly tight experience. This game doesn't stand out because of any "hook" or big gimmick; it stands out because of the pure, polished, and refined yet simple experience it gives you. It's just a simple 2D Zelda-like, just done perfect.

146254422.review:
Decent, but very flawed game.

I'll start out with the positives. Like anybody else I get interested of this game because of its visual style. The characters looks like they comme from Hayao Miyazaki film and the level design is in the style of Monument Valley. 

The visual part is the strongest of the game. Everything else is mid or not good. The music is nice, but forgettable. The controls are decent, but could be less delayed.

About the negatives. Trying to navigate without a map is a handicap. I guess it's not there because of the secret locations, but it doesn't justify it. Half of the time you get lost because everything look the same. Imagine not having a map in a Metroid game. The weapons are all the same, you end up using the first weapon through out the whole game. The power ups barely change the combat. They add so little that I thought that it was broken. You barely feel any difference in power when you maxing up a stat. Last thing which could look insignificant is the sound design of swinging the sword. There's not satisfying sound when you are swinging the weapon. 

It's inspired by many games, but it doesn't do hommage to their legacy, it just copies some mechanics and turn them into a shallow game play eventually. It's a game that doesn't need to exist at the end.

146150919.review:
Jefferson is real and he is my friend. 

     Death's door is truly a very enjoyable game, with a wide range of characters, exploration, and enemy diversity to keep things spicy. The characters have fun, dynamic dialogue to draw you into the world, with some being quite relaxed and natural, and others feeling more grand. The overall assortment of personalities found throughout Death's door make each interaction joyous and fun. The combat based on a relatively simple short ranged + long ranged + dodge system, but, it's cranked to a nice level which gives fighting foes challenging, in addition to each creature you face having a unique pattern for takedown.
     
Having 100%ed the game on my first save, I appreciate the level of detail put into the world of Death's Door, giving players vast opportunities to find hidden gems of story and gameplay along their journey. If players choose to follow the main story only, the game has a satisfying relative playtime, but if players want to wander the maps, there is a significant chunk of playtime that is worth spending. The story itself is rich, and the theme that is explored really shines a light on the hues of death, grief, and healing. The darker overall meaning of the game is brought out through incredible time you spend in game, as you piece together a worthwhile adventure. 
    
 In the total scheme of the game, there is very little I find worth noting that is bad about the game. It's risk/reward system for fighting and exploration is well balanced, and the only complaint I would have is the amount of walking required. On the other hand, having gone for 100%, I chose to spend the time walking, where the average player will most likely not run into this issue so much. 
    
 I appreciate Death's Door, I absolutely think it was worth playing. I love the art style, world building, characters, combat, and more. Would very much recommend :)

146010753.review:
This is a weird one, and I like them that way. Mechanically, it's more metroidvania than soulslike, the combat isn't terribly complicated or hard and that was an intentional choice. The really interesting stuff is the storytelling and the puzzle design, both of which are quite good. This game is full of human touches, like the funerals for the bosses after you kill them, and the collectibles have the souls quality of sometimes giving gameplay hints, so keep an eye out for that.
So go ahead and play it, it's more than worth your time. 

!!!SERIOUS SPOILERS FROM HERE ON OUT!!!

If you haven't got the true ending (??? achievement on steam) I'd highly advise getting it, it's a very strong element of the story in my opinion.

Okay? Okay.

The third act, with the Yeti, is the weakest one in my opinion. Learning about prior lords of doors is great and all, but the thing I liked about act 1 and 2 was the threats seemed active, like there was an unfolding situation. Betty (her name's Betty, right?) is just not as much of a presence as the Frog King and Grandma, both of which represent actual moral failings, as opposed to the dark souls thing of "this just lived a really long time and is messed up now." The real strength of this game is where is breaks out of that trope - goes into what people actually would end up like in a world without death, which I'd compare to Dark Souls II if the restraining order would let me.
So when you cross into the door, and there's nothing but an infinite white plane, driving your mentor mad from the wasted time - that's a great moment, and a great boss fight. That's really the moment that made me realize this game was worth talking about.
And then, the Lord of Doors totally sticks the landing! Best villain monologue of its type, the Lord is both completely a villain and innately understandable. The fight is great: the first phase is cinematic without being railroady, and the second is the game's most complex and interesting melee combat that doesn't take you too off-guard. It's a great end to the story.
But then, the post-game stuff is also really good, paying off unique oddities in the world and inviting the player to revisit the old puzzles with some new enemies and bosses. Whereas a lot of combat-heavy games feel draining to go back over, replaying the areas in Death's Door is mellow and puzzly, which would be boring if you hadn't had to fight for your life the last time you were here. It's a great way to solidify the world as a real place, and the puzzles all build up an intriguing final reveal.
...which honestly doesn't live up to expectations for me. The final cutscene shows a lot of effort, clearly someone cares deeply about the lore they were looking to elaborate on, but it just doesn't feel built-up in the same way as the main story. It's more of a teaser for a future game than an explanation of the new mysteries we've encountered. But hey, if Death's Door 2 ever came out (preferably with a less crap name) then I'd absolutely buy it, make no mistake. This is an excellent little game, and I hope the developers feel accomplished and willing to take these kinds of risks on future projects.

145994960.review:
Short version: This game is lots of fun. Buy it if you want a fun single-player game.

Long version: This game is great; probably one of the best single-player games I've ever played. It reminds me more of the old-school style of games with a short but fun self-contained story. The combat is very simple: attack, dodge, and spells, but the enemies manage to keep the game at a difficulty that lets you plow through most fights easily, but you can still die if you make a few small mistakes. Another key aspect of this game is puzzles. Most of them are short and sweet. They might make you think a little bit but they never feel too hard to understand or too easy to the extent that they've overstayed their welcome. Another aspect that I've seen most games ignore is the soundtrack. This game nails it. It has some of the best OSTs of any game I've played. I've seen some people complain about a lack of map in these reviews, but don't let that sway you. The game isn't a maze, and unless you have the spatial memory of a fly you won't get too lost. That said, this game isn't without flaws: the biggest being a select few of the puzzles being absolute BS to understand, and while most of those are optional, some are required, adding some unneeded frustration to the game.
Overall, I'd give it a 10/10. There isn't much better they could do to this game.

145399355.review:
I am incredibly disappointed at this game. 
This negative review does not mean the game is rubbish, but rather that, for me, it falls short in all vital points. In fact, the quality surprised me in the beginning.
I went in blind and got hooked by the tight controls, interesting settings and great music. Combat was fun too. Yet soon, this initial interest was lost upon tedious yet boring exploring, a story that never quite kicked off, progression with little meaning and impact, all to similar enemy varieties and bland secrets. 
It is not one big flaw that made this game unlikable, it’s the sum of many small aspects which in the end covered its redeeming factor. That being said, it does have good reviews, so I do wonder if I’m simply not the target audience, then again, this genre and setting is what I normally love. 
One of my biggest gripes about this game is the lack of a map. I know this was done to increase immersion, and maybe it was done being inspired by tough as nail games with frequent deaths, but in this game it does not work. While exploring I barely ever died, and the world, partly though the top-down view is just too repetitive to be rememberable. This, together with the fact that I played this game with some breaks in-between meant that immersion was constantly broken by tedious searches to find that one secret I swore I saw somewhere. 
In the end, I gave up searching for secrets, knowing I missed on some hidden content. Yet what I found was too unrewarding to make up for the loss of time. This means though that my game time is bloated and you can subtract maybe 2-3 hours from it, had the game not forced me into these search periods. 
In addition, I personally HATE true endings and secret final bosses. This is purely personal and some disagree, but the way the game expects you to run around after you slain the normal final boss to search for all that nonsense just for a short scene, I can look up on youtube is crazy. This completely ruined the post game feeling for me and left a bitter taste for this game that has some amazing aspects, yet far far too many downsides and gameplay decisions which ruined the experience for me.

144774995.review:
I highly recommend this game to any fan of "dark souls" style of games. This is a fun experience with nice graphics and really well made music (not distracting, enhances the atmosphere, love it). Difficulty can seem steep at first, especially if you try to bulldoze your way through the game - it looks like a hack-and-slash, it runs like a hack-and-slash at first, but, essentially, it's Dark Souls in an unusual dressing.

The main attraction of the game is slow, methodical combat. Take your time, learn your opponent's attack patterns, movement patterns and you'll do just fine. I tried to play in a "button-mash, beat-em-up style", just to get pounced again and again by the computer opponents. But then I learned to take it slow and the combat became easier and the game became much more enjoyable!

The story is nice, although it may be aimed at a specific type of personality or world view. The jokes thrown around the game are fun and a pleasant distraction from all the combat.

The game is rather short, you can beat it and 100% it in under 20 hours. The game packs enough content to keep things fresh for the duration of the game, with some minor backtracking to collect things you couldn't reach at an earlier point. There are some missable achievements, but you can either do a second play-through, or study missable achievements beforehand. I'd recommend a 2nd playthrough, though, I'm doing one right now and I'm enjoying it a lot.

Amazing music, graphics, art style and combat mechanics. No menus, micro transactions, loot boxes, text on the screen or cluttered UI. Just a short, compact, lovely game to play in a world that feels really nice to exist in. A little challenging for me, but not insurmountable, so it feels very rewarding. Cracks in the enemies instead of health bars is genius and also looks amazing/adds to the immersion of combat, the UI when you're playing is so clean it's like it's not even there and there's enough variation in skills/weapons to play how you want to. The game rewards exploration and it's one of those games where you want to explore, which is very rare these days. It's also linear, which I think the gaming world needs to realise is absolutely fine, not everything needs to be a giant open world that is 90% empty, I much prefer a smaller world that is dense with content. The puzzles are simple but also just calming as you go through the story. 

Wish it was longer but also love that it tells the story it is here to tell and very much looking forward to what comes next for these developers.

Verdict: 7/10
A relaxing light action game in a wonderful world clearly inspired by Studio Gibli. The main character is adorable and the controls are smooth. At times the game has a very slow pace (sometimes borderlining boring), can be grindy and requires patience, because it forces you to walk through the same areas repeatedly for some secrets. Also, while the setting is charming I found the story itself a bit non-sensical and confusingly told. The world is inviting yet there is unfortunately not much to do other than fighting and solving some puzzles, which is sad because it feels like there could have been much more - interestingly, AFTER you have finished the game, you can do some stuff to achieve the true ending and these challenges have some of the "magical"  RPG-ish feeling that is missing a bit in the main game. 

I recommend it if you are looking for a relaxing light action game to wind down after a hard day of work and forget your troubles in a beautiful charming world - if you are willing to bring some patience.

I really like the game. The vibe, levels, sound is all good, and a decent story. However, the combat doesn't feel good or satisfying. Upgrades are useless, you have to always dance around even small enemies or you get hit. Aggressive play is punished and you're forced into turn base combat. Especially with the bosses. You have range ability? Oh the boss just jumps on your head while you channel it. Every boss, every elite enemy. Whats the point? The combat ends up being boring and repetitive, where you roll hit roll hit roll hit, until the sponge boss is dead. It forces you to use two moves only. When a boss channels an ability it tracks until the end, and you get hit when you think you are safe. For example, the beast jumps into the air before a roll, you try to dodge roll behind him... but no you silly goose, he spins 180 in the air and still hits you. Where is the fun in combat if you cant use the small variety of skills and moves you have.

Finally, to 100% the game, you have two play it twice, because you have to only use the umbrella. A extra weapon you start with, which is not the default. Thanks, but no thanks.

143336596.review:
A wholly enjoyable experience. Simple, but fun combat mechanics. A simple, but nice art direction. A few locations to explore, a few secrets to find, a few slightly challenging fights, a few weirdo characters with a few lines of whimsical dialogue - Death's Door doesn't do particularly much, but what it does, it does particularly well.

Things I didn't like quite as much:
- Level design isn't exactly memorable. Many levels (the graveyard, the garden, the flooded fortress, notably) are just an assortment of unremarkable rooms or plateaus without any greater structure or purpose. This is the reason why other reviews want a map, I guess - there is just nothing there to remember your path by.
- The puzzles are rather basic and obvious, even for action RPG standards.
- The soundtrack is great on its own, but the virtuosic, romantic pieces don't fit the simplified and whimsical look and feel of the remaining game.
- The game needs slightly more variety - say, a very few more enemies and a very few more combat mechanics.

143312902.review:
Atmosphere is king in this game. The game has a really amazing ability to set the tone with a really great OST, set and character design with some meaningful messages behind it. Unfortunately quite often the dialogue ruins these moments with out of place references and "lol XD random" jokes.

Also an interesting choice to have HP and MP upgrades hidden so obscurely within the environment while also having to complete challenges, while random collectable junk for world building is much easier to find. I beat the game on the starting hp and mp because the shrines were just not obvious to me, except for the ones I backtracked for.

I really had to fight the urge as well to not ignore the enemies, the amount of exp they drop and the fact they are so easily bypassed 99% of the time really didn't give me an incentive to fight mobs on each death. If you do though it makes the experience more enjoyable.

Another really great entry into the isometric "souls-like" genre. It's got a lot of really great macro ideas with a lot of small, frustrating micro ideas sprinkled in.

142980380.review:
[h2]Not What I Envisioned[/h2]
Having played Titan Souls a long time ago, I decided to buy Death's Door. Well, my honest thoughts could be summarised as follows: this is a great game, done masterfully and is pretty much a guide on how to make a good game in general. It shows how Acid Nerve has developed over the years and matured.

Everything works as expected: no bugs, at least for my experience; smooth animations, clean and distinctive visuals.
And yet... The overall package felt underwhelming, at least for me.

Don't get me wrong, I've enjoyed playing this game, but I can't deny that it doesn't really feel like an Acid Nerve game. Given that they've not made countless games, it may sound a bit over the top, but what they have established with Titan Souls was pretty clear.

Let me explain. I'll start with what convinced me, and then I'll dive more into the reason behind what I've said before.

[h3]The Good[/h3]
I think that, visually, the game looks good. It's straight to the point, clean, recognisable. When you first start your journey, the greyness of it all sure will catch your eye, no doubt about that. Combine that with a really solid, catchy soundtrack and you've got an appealing bundle.

I appreciate the fact that the items you pick up can turn out to be useful to unlock certain things, areas and such. At first, I didn't really pay much attention to what I've picked up, simply acknowledging the items, but when I started to notice I was pleasantly surprised. 

[h3]The Other Stuff[/h3]
Okay, so. Bare in mind that this can be summarised as a "Meh" section.
First of all, I was really bothered by the fact that a studio which made its boss battles titanic, epic, memorable, settled down for a more washed up experience. In Death's Door, the structure is very much different, yet pretty basic: you have your normal, elite and boss enemies. There are some secrets here and there too, but even there not much to really keep you invested.

What bothers me is that each encounter in Titan Souls was really memorable, harder and certainly more "fair". Not that it isn't fair here, in fact it is way too easy! I haven't struggled even a bit while playing this, which can be good to some, but I expected more. Here, you'll have to settle with the fact that you'll be mostly dealing with weak, repetitive mobs and elite enemies that really have too little variations to be appreciated fully.

This is the best example of quality over quantity. While there were many bosses in Titan Souls, the fact that there were no mobs made it much more intimate and challenging. More original, too. I would have never expected to treat enemy encounters as a chore in an Acid Nerve game.

I've said before that Titan Souls was more "fair", and yet I've said that Death's Door is really easy. How come? Well... it all comes down to the core combat design choices. In titan souls, you had an arrow, and the enemy had a weak point. It was [i]fair[/i]. And, on top of that, when you managed to defeat the enemy, you had that moment of silence. You really felt the weight of your actions.

Here, well... not really. Having mobs around and encountering a small amount of bosses really made me lose sight of how important my duty as a Reaper was. Well, if I had to stay true to the lore, feeling like this should be canon since being a Reaper is like having a full-time job. I don't think there are many memorable moments in Death's Door, if at all.

Maybe the only memorable ones were the true ending and a certain boss in a graveyard, but that's it.

If it weren't Acid Nerve, maybe I would act differently, but... Ugh.

The last thing I want to talk about is dialogue... I really think it doesn't give anything to the game, and it doesn't feel engaging as it should be. It felt flat, strangely comical, and it tries to build up lore without taking itself seriously as it should've. Narration in Titan Souls was way more effective, and no one ever had a line of dialogue there. 

As someone mentioned in another review, level design really lacks here too. I remember the labyrinth forest in Titan Souls in order to get to the boss, and it was an interesting design choice. The world made you invested. Here, not so much... I was just going from point A to point B while pulling some levers and having the same boss dialogue structure in different areas.

There are some honorable mentions, though. The Old Watchtowers were cool, in my opinion. And the Estate Of The Urn Witch was interesting, too.

[h2]So... Bad Game?[/h2]
No, it isn't a bad game. It just felt flat and generic, especially after a few hours. It's a game done by the book, flawless in the implementation, with all the elements working properly and a solid gameplay. It just didn't resonate with me at all, as if it hadn't a solid story to tell. 

I still recommend you to play this, because of how good the development side of things is, because it makes you appreciate how talented these developers are.

142617216.review:
Death's Door is one of my favorite games. Its art style is wonderful, and the story is simple and fun. However, my love for Death's Door comes from its movement and combat, which are responsive, engaging, and exciting.

My favorite part of the game was the grapple ability, which is incredibly fun to use, both when exploring and in combat.

I was also impressed by the hidden secrets of Death's Door, which can be challenging but fair to find. I even liked the post-game secret hunt that led to the true ending, although some of those secrets became a little tedious to find.

142602257.review:
I had a lot of fun with this game. The first thing that instantly sticks out is the game's sense of humor. There are a lot of fun characters with funny little quirks that, while not strictly necessary, add a lot to the world. Exploration is also very interesting, with tons of secrets and shortcuts to find. I do have to say that it can be frustrating going back through the areas trying to find what you missed, especially in the endgame and post game, but I'll get into that later. Combat is perfectly satisfying. You do just enough damage to feel like every hit counts, and I rarely felt as if it was unfair. Unfortunately, it isn't balanced very well for the weapons that aren't the default sword, but it's still fun.
Most of my complaints with the game are minor nitpicks that relate to endgame content, so kinda spoilery stuff ahead, but I'll try to keep my language ambiguous. There are some things that the game, for some reason, doesn't really tell you or even hint at. It took me ages to realize how access sewers, or even that those weird circular platforms were sewer entrances and not some mystical teleportation pad. Also, there is an attack some late game bosses do that slows you down to the point of barely being able to avoid anything. I was on my third or fourth attempt of the final boss when I realized you had to mash to get out, which didn't feel like me gaining skill in the fight, and just left me feeling stupid.
As for the post game, most of it is pretty fun. New secrets are accessible in all the areas, with stronger enemies around everywhere. However, there is one thing that is incredibly infuriating. One of the items you need is locked behind a door which only opens once you've planted every seed in the game. This is mostly fine, since most seed pots are easy to find just in the normal process of playing, but you'll definitely need hints to find the last few. The problem is that the NPC which gives you these hints is at the door for which you need the seeds, but he isn't there when you arrive. You have to leave and go back to the area, which is not at all intuitive and cost me lots of time before I read a guide and realized that he appeared if you went back. Whatever, one small annoying quest, surely the true ending is worth it? ...Not really. When I went into the room you can get to after doing everything else, I thought it was a boss arena, and when this big [spoiler] showed up and was presented exactly the same way all the bosses were, I thought I would get a cool climactic superboss. Instead it's just... a cutscene. A cool cutscene, which brings some loose threads together and has cool implications, but still just a cutscene.
But please, don't let what I've said dissuade you from buying this game. It's still got a solid core of gameplay and story, and I had a blast playing through the main bulk of it. Just don't do the full post game like I did.

142576783.review:
Death's Door is an intriguing game with a great story, captivating visuals and a decent combat system.

[b] Combat: [/b] Basic and repetitive, but fun enough. It's a hack and slash. You use a melee weapon that has a light attack, a charged attack and a dash attack. For ranged combat you have 3 spells. There isn't really variety in weapons, since they are very few and only change stats like slightly more damage, faster attack speed and bigger reach.
Unfortunately, outside the bosses, the enemies have very few attack patterns. The majority of the time you are just mashing the light attack button and then dash away to dodge an attack, maybe use a spell to attack from range, and then repeat for the next encounter.

[b] Environment: [/b] Enthralling and mysterious dark fantasy world with hand-crafted landscapes offering haunting beauty and unique charm. The visually striking environments play a crucial role in enhancing the narrative and gameplay, creating a memorable and immersive experience throughout the game. I would say this is the strongest feature of this game.
Traversing through the environment is semi-linear, where you unlock different paths with new abilities found in the previously explored locations. The only complain I have for this is the lack of a map to visualise the overall connection between different places in the game.  

[b] Sound: [/b] It features an atmospheric sound design that complements its environments, immersing players in the mysterious world of the game. The audio enhances the overall experience.

[b] Story: [/b] The lore of Death's Door is charismatic, drawing players into its unique world of crows as reapers and the balance between life and death. With its incorporation of ancient civilizations, forgotten deities, and thought-provoking themes, the lore enriches the narrative, making the game a truly memorable and engaging experience.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]
Death's Door stands as an outstanding experience, captivating players with its extraordinary narrative and captivating visuals. The combat, though well-executed, may leave some wanting in terms of weapon variety and added combat functionalities. Nonetheless, this minor drawback hardly detracts from the overall brilliance of the game, making it a must-play for fans of action-adventure titles and those looking to be enthralled by a rich and engaging world.

142484747.review:
I recommend this game if you get it discounted. 
I 100% completed it in around 12 hours (had the game running while away from home) and I wasn't really satisfied at the end.

The game is overall a nice metroidvenia experience with a very basic combat and upgrade system and the standard stuff you get in a metroidvenia, like upgrades that open up sections of previous parts of the game, but it feels empty sometimes.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat is very easy, you basically get a basic light attack combo, a charged attack, dash attack and some spells. There isn't really variety in weapons since they just change some stats like slightly more damage or faster attacks (aside the hammer perhaps, it does a lightning effect when hitting enemies but I used it very little).
Unfortunately the enemies outside the first and maybe last boss have very few attack patterns. The optimal strategy is just doing a full string (or almost) and then dash away, then repeat. This, for every encounter in the game. The only difficult spikes are at the beginning, when you do the least damage, and when there are multiple ranged enemies, but nothing too extreme. The game would have been far better with more enjoable encounters.

[h1]Upgrade System[/h1]
This is maybe the weakest part of the game. You get to choose 4 types of upgrades (melee damage, movement speed, attack speed, ranged damage) 5 times each, but are so marginal they could have just removed them and the game wouldn't change that much. For example you need the strongest weapon and 4/5 strenght upgrades to one-shot the basic enemy (instead of 2 hit with the basic weapon and no upgrades). 

[h1]World Building[/h1]
Envirnoments and lore are fine, nothing too deep but definitely enjoyable. The worlds are fairly small overall, but packed with secrets and stuff to collect.

[h1]Post-end game and Backtracking[/h1]
Being a Metroidvania you will do backtracking at some point for secrets and upgrades, if you enjoy the genre it's exactly what you're looking for. In this game, backtracking contends the spot for weakest part of the game with the upgrade system. The first time you unlock the final upgrade you definitly still enjoy the game because you know where to look, or you just wonder around discovering stuff. But once you finish the main game you basically unlock a new "version" of the entire game map that is no other than the world with maybe very slight differences, new dialogues, new secrets to discover and basically no enemies for a large part of the game. This wouldn't be a problem if you had movement skills or just faster movement. Like I said, the upgrades are very marginal and a maxed out movement speed isn't fast, just slightly faster. And you walk around very, very, much. The last 3-4 hours of the game was just that, wondering around slowly. There is a quest in which you have to traverse across the map by foot without using teleports, it was the most boring 15 minutes of the game. And what's the reward for all that? The last item for your "random items" collection, couple of boss fights (at this point of the game you're maxed out and you know the strategy) and a "true ending" that basically tells you nothing that exciting. I would recommend to just look all that stuff up, it isn't really worth experiencing in my opinion.

[h1]Conclusion: 7/10[/h1]
At the end I would still give the game a decent grade, the main part of the game is enjoyble even without a decent upgrtade system and repetitive encounters (that foruntately are very fast at least) and is definitely a good 8-10 hours.
Could have been a little gem with a little more depth.

I personally can't recommend this game. It's too basic and gets repetitive. I didn't feel a sense of exploration or discovery because the levels are small linear corridors and the rewards are almost always the same, so all it had going for it was the combat and world-building. There's a sort of rpg level-up mechanic, but it's so bare-bones, it's hardly worth mentioning. The world-building is actually great, but the combat is lacking. You could tentatively call it a soulslike, though it's a bit easy as those tend to go. When they do try to make it difficult, it's just by spamming a bunch of enemies, not through creatively built encounters. Annoyance with the enemy spam outweighed the fun I was having around the 6 hour mark so I stopped playing.
Honestly, if Steam had a "meh" option, that's what I'd choose.

142376761.review:
The visual style is very charming, and the characters are nice, if reminiscent. the basic combat loop is pretty well designed, and the puzzles are pretty good, but I have quite a few issues with the game.

mini bosses and even most bosses have two or three attacks that they repeat until death while having a ton of health so the big fights outside of the last two or three are relatively boring.

the upgrade, weapon and spell systems all do barely anything to effect the way you play the game. the stat increases are slight enough that they are barely noticable until you get at least half of them in a catagory, and all the weapons play almost the same way just with different damage values. The first three spells are used the same way in combat and actually do the same damage as each other, but are used slightly differently in progression.

the mobbing combat is generally pretty good, but suffers from lack of variety. you will see three enemy types throughout the game: melee enemies, ranged enemies, and magic enemies. most variants of them don't do anything unique, beside maybe attack twice, or explode.

Overall the game is intensely mediocre, probably skip it.

142341480.review:
[h1]One of the great hidden gems on steam[/h1]

A visual masterpiece with tight controls, enjoyable progression, interesting story (that doesn't [i]force[/i] you to care) and a stop-when-you've-had-enough endgame. I got the "real ending" but I won't be doing the umbrella challenge. The real ending for me was the right sweet spot where completing the last few things would be more tedious than fun for me and that's totally fine.

As the spiritual success to Titan Soul, it achieves something that few other games do in terms of successfully translating a 2D game into a 3D one. Now before you say that the game basically takes place on a series of 2D layers, that's not the point. There are still difficult technical challenges in that format that would have been different to Titan Souls and a lot of gameplay can fall through those gaps if the developers don't put in enough care. Acid Nerve obviously [i]do[/i] care that care can be felt in all kinds of enjoyable little details through the entire world.

I highly recommend this game to pretty much anyone. I'm not a hardcore gamer and as I've gotten older, I've become more impatient (since games compete with a more complex like than when I was a teenager). In short, I don't have the patience to try the same thing over and over and to weather the frustration of time lost to a challenge curve that's too steep. Death's Door hit my curve pretty much perfectly.

If I am to make one criticism is that I played this game for a bit about a year ago but then put it down for a while. When I came back to it, there was no clear way for me to know what I was doing. I basically had to run around aimlessly until I triggered an event. That is to say, the game is best played inside a time-window where you can keep what you were doing in your mind. That said, the only penalty for not doing this is a bit of running around and trying to find the right event trigger or NPC to talk to.

The endgame is handled particularly well, however. Without spoiling anything, there are clear signals to indicate which parts of the world require more attention and which can be ignored making the final explore and completion phase more dense with meaningful gameplay.

All up, best game I've played for a long time and maybe the best of its genre I've ever played. I can not wait for the next thing Acid Nerve are cooking up.

142331596.review:
So. I realize i might not be the core audience of this game. But still. 
This is a wonderful game, it´s got atmosphere, a great story, magnificent art direction. The exploration is super rewarding and fun. some of it´s bossfights are super fun, others... are not. And that´s exactly where we are at the heart of the problem.

I managed to get through most of the game. i struggled, i was frustrated at times, but i got through because i want to love this game.

The final Boss fight is a bad joke.
Take every skill that was ever hard to evade by all the bosses, slap it into one boss, but make it random and faster. oh and when you finally get further than you ever had, new skill. never before seen, no warning, hardly telegraphed. dead.

i loved this game until i reached this point. i spent 11 hours getting here and won´t be able to finish it. because this doesn´t feel like trial and error, learning a bosses mechanics, getting better every time, this feels like getting relentlessly floored by a random assortment of skills you sometimes just cannot avoid.

His first phase is magnificent. A climax as i would have hoped for. but then we get what i described above and any forwards momentum falls apart. plus, thanks to the autosave, you can not even go back out to upgrade. you´re just stuck. tough luck, start over.
This is not just hard. it is unfair. at least put in a warning. "if you go beyond this point you can not come back" or something.


TldR do not buy this game it is not worth the frustration of it´s final boss fight.

I would recommend this game but not because it's an AMAZING game, but it's a good game.
The graphics and art direction is great, I love the world they built. The controls are smooth and responsive, every death I suffered was my own fault. I had fun through the whole game!
The story is a little bland but had a lot of potential. A lot. The combat at some points, was repetitive. It still was fun, but didn't try to change or spice it up throughout the game. In this game, there's no map, you just have to remember things as you go. The game itself doesn't give you any reason to backtrack. This left the game feel a bit railroaded, even if you have the ability to go back and explore. I, personally, never felt the desire to go back to past areas.
All in all, a solid game. It took 11 hours (I restarted since I left the game then came back to it) to complete, if you like "souls-like", top-down zelda gameplay, this game will scratch that itch well.

141296526.review:
7/10 Game

If you want someone's attempt at making a spiritual companion to Link to the Past, Death's Door puts in an honest effort to do that, but comes up short in the places that really matter. The set pieces, the characters, and the style are something to be celebrated in this title, but as you get your hands around the game itself, you may be struggling with clunky combat that tries to be Dark Souls with an emphasis on dodging and timing attacks.

The combat is shallow and does not take any intuitive approaches to the combat encounters as it feels like this game was primarily designed around having the main sword through the whole game. No other weapon does anything particularly well and they do not offer any tooling that makes them necessary to use. For example, the thunder hammer should be used to break enemies with invulnerable armor, opening them for attack with your sword. Instead, it's another useless addition to your inventory slots.

Play A Link to the Past instead, but if the basic set-pieces and charming characters are enough to grab you, they certainly deliver.

141096067.review:
[h1]Gameplay: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 7/10[/h1]

✔️ Very beautiful art direction - incredible low poly graphics with beautiful shaders, very nice character and environment designs, great music and visual effects!
✔️ Very nice general game feel.
✔️ The NPC telling you what you missed in the game so far is a pretty cool design choice.
✔️ The puzzles are simple but offer a pretty fun change of pace next to pretty challenging combat.
✔️ Intriguing and cute story, though nothing transcendental.

💭 The magic design is a bit bland in my opinion - I mean the magic spells work very well, especially as puzzle keys, but "in fine" they are all very similar to each other. Having some more diverse magic spells would have been pretty rad.

❌ Honestly I found the game too difficult. I regret the absence of some difficulty / accessibility options, and on such I would have placed the current difficulty higher than average. The difficulty presented by the game is a mix of "fair" difficulty offered by enemies whose patterns you can observe, learn, and overcome, and "unfair" difficulty, where the game just throws too many enemies at you and you have to somehow arrange to still read their patterns in this mess, with sometimes the collisions pushing you in weird ways across the map, and sometimes enemies chaining several points of damage on you without much of an opportunity window. I somehow finished this game but quite a few battles were very painful to play through.

I loved discovering this game, playing through its puzzles, exploring its world, but I kinda hated part of the game's combat, especially the parts that were actually designed to be harder. I admit that it might be at least in part due to me not being the target audience, but I really think I would have enjoyed the game far more with difficulty options allowing to make enemies slower, or less numerous or make them shoot les projectiles, or something, I don't know. Despite that, it's still a good game, and I definitely recommend it for people who look for a bit of a challenge.

140788950.review:
This game succeeds in almost everything it sets out to do. 
The art work and music are great.
The controls are tight and fluid.
The enemies are varied with easy to learn move sets.
The level design is impeccable.
The story is pretty darn good, nothing to write home about in my opinion, but good for the game play.
And on top of all of that is the pacing, there was never a single point in either of my two play-throughs that I felt lost or didn't have an idea of what to do or where to go.

My only two complaints are small:
1) There is mini boss mechanic whose counter isn't communicated in the best way, but this doesn't impact the fight in any significant way, so not that big of a deal.
2) There being a lack of perspective based puzzles or secrets. Don't get me wrong, there are a few. But, this being an isometric game, there aren't enough. This reinforces a paranoid style of play (like me) where the player is scouring every single nook and cranny looking for secrets and puzzles where (a majority of the time.) there aren't any. It's not a major problem at all (especially if you're going for 100% completion.), more a personal preference.

All in all, this game is great. Definitely worth the price.

140637479.review:
Fun little metroidvania about soul-reaping crows. Moderately difficult. Mostly silly, but with a few good heartfelt moments, as one would expect from a game that has death as its central theme.

Warning, however, to the completionists: the achievements of this game are designed in an infuriating "get 100% of everything to get any achievements at all" kind of way. Simply completing the game will get you maybe three achievements. Getting every collectable - many of which can't even be gotten before defeating the final boss - plus completing the secret epilogue will get you the other twenty-one.

140618294.review: A great game. It was quite slow during the beginning, due to the lackluster movement in the early stages, which was why I maxed haste first, allowing backtracking and overall movement easier and more efficient. The combat felt fluid and smooth, and enemies' attacks could be dodged on the first attempt if you were fast enough; of course, some bosses had me die multiple times in order to successfully vanquish them into death's cold embrace. I had beaten the main bosses without upgrading strength or magic, as I had maxed dexterity after maxing haste, as well as using the [spoiler] Rouge Daggers [/spoiler] throughout the entire run. Though I have collected all the weapons and all the spell upgrades, I rarely used spells outside of the [spoiler]  Grappling Hook [/spoiler] for rolling out of an attack and going right back in; I absolutely love the movement capabilities it bestows upon the player. Whilst writing this, I have yet to fully upgrade magic or strength; though I have gotten all shiny things, all seeds, and the true ending. If you want help for secrets, an NPC named Jefferson will give you riddles of secrets that you can attain with your current abilities; you won't find him till later on though, so don't go randomly searching for him until you get your first ability. This game is more story based if you want to fully complete this game for the true ending; as you need to use some shiny things for different secrets. The Academy of Umbrellas achievement is not worth your sanity though; I don't suggest trying to attain it.

140338790.review:
I've played for a couple of hours and while this game is drop dead gorgeous, it unfortunately feels very boring to play.

In a game like this, I would expect the story to be a motivating factor for the player, but it seems that they've missed the mark for me. While the story incorporates elements of the hero's journey, as the MC is forced to embark on an adventure, the main character feels like a pawn being moved around without any agency of their own. (Thereby giving the player the same feeling.) 

At the start of the game you get screwed over, but are then forced to do the job of the guy that screwed you over because "Well, sorry, but I'm too old to do it and you can't go back so what else are you gonna do lol? Grow old and die?" What kind of motivation is that? It turns the entire game into a chore I'm doing for *somebody else* who is already inherently unlikable. Why? If I was seeking my revenge against him, or leading an investigation into the theft, or if there was any more mystery to it besides "there's this door, something neat might be behind it if you finish the game", I might feel more compelled to play, but right now? I just don't.

The game has decent puzzles, but has combat that so far feels very same-y. I obtained a new weapon, and while it was supposedly different than my sword, it didn't feel different enough to warrant changing my play style at all, so I just ended up playing the same as I had been. 

I've encountered some bosses, and sometimes I wish they'd telegraph their movements a bit better, although it's not terrible. There was one mini boss I had to fight three times, but the 2nd and 3rd time was just the same boss but with infinitely spawning adds, which didn't particularly impress me. Additionally, for many bosses it felt like there wasn't a moment of respite where the boss was recovering from its big attacks for me to go ham on it, like I would kind of expect there to be. There was just the brief period between the attack they just finished and their next attack. I didn't particularly like this rhythm of boss fights, although this may be personal preference.

All in all, It's serviceable. If that's good enough for you, then by all means, get the game, but I don't think I'm going to play it much more. It feels too polished to give it a low score, but in my opinion, its execution keeps it from being truly enjoyable. 
5/10

140018020.review:
Finally, a Dark Souls game for people like me. Wage slaves with zero time to ‘get good’ and a desperate need for some positivity in the gloom.

This is a delightful game. The atmosphere strikes a nice balance, blending grim drudgery and unrestrained tyranny with bright humor and hope that things will get better. The animations are smooth and rife with small details that add charm and character to the world. The gameplay is challenging enough to be fun, but not too difficult. Something a gamer with a full time job can still make progress in without sacrificing all their free time to the game. It also does a good job encouraging exploration, with lots of opportunities to not only power up the character, but also to learn little bites about the world they’re in through hidden objects and their associated stories. The overall storyline is pretty obvious, but not overt, so it keeps it interesting to follow along with as the player progresses the plot.

This game borrows *heavily* from Dark Souls. So if you were ever interested in that game, but felt intimidated by the high difficulty bar, or if you’ve played the game and want a quick breath of something new but familiar, I would strongly suggest this game.

Si os mola este rollo o habéis jugado al Titan souls, os va a gustar, ya que son de los mismos creadores y se nota en su fluidez de combate y su ambiente. 
Titulo totalmente recomendado.

No han querido buscar ninguna novedad gigantesca, creo que es un juego básico en ese aspecto, pero no con ello malo, ni mucho menos.

-Gráficamente me parece un arte simple, pero la ambientación que logran, me parece increíble, es muy bonito. 
 Zonas y ambientes muy curiosos.

-En rendimiento, nada que decir, el juego corre espectacular. Dudo que alguien tenga algún problema.

-El combate se basa en ataques cuerpo a cuerpo, aunque también hay magias. Disponemos de 5 armas en total, con 2-3 tipos de variantes 
 en los golpes y 4 habilidades, la cual a mi me ha encantado por su facilidad en el movimiento y combos 
 rápidos, que es, el arpón.

-Diseño de niveles, simplemente magnifico, zonas no muy grandes, pero con sus escondrijos, puzzles, atajos... 
 muchos de ellos muy curiosos de encontrar. No se hace tedioso el hecho de buscar cosas.

-Como algo un poco negativo, por decir algo, sería el tema enemigos, se ve un poco escaso de variedad. 
 Bosses de patrones la mayoría fáciles de pillar rápido.

-Historia bonita, me gusta el drama que se monta y la tergiversación que ocurre en ella. Hay frases muy buenas.
 -Hay bastantes bromas y personajes payasetes que dan una vidilla guay a la trama.

-La dificultad de este titulo no es nada del otro mundo, si lograste superar Titan souls, este no te va a resultar ningún problema. Pero creo que la dificultad que ocupa este juego es buena para cualquier persona.

139909811.review:
Лучшая метроидвания в изометрии, в которую я когда-либо играл.
Стильная графика, красивые спецэффекты, потрясающая боевка, уникальные боссы и увлекающий сюжет - все это тут присутствует.
Для любителей посложнее, можно взять зонтик в качестве оружия и пробежать с ним всю игру - даже ачивку получите. Несмотря на то, что, на первый взгляд, такое повышение сложности только за счет того, что зонтик слабее дефолтного меча в два раза, выглядит халтурно, это не привносит ощущения растянутости геймплея. Да, вы будете ковырять врагов дольше, но ощущается это все еще справедливо, ведь вторую половину игры после вкачки статов вы вообще будете выносить всех с одного-двух ударов обычным оружием, а с зонтиком же будете более вдумчиво подходить к схваткам.
Еще из того, что понравилось, в игре продумано много деталей, чтобы облегчить геймплей даже самым лютым дрочилам, типа меня, которые хотят вылизать игру и пройти ее на 150%, собрав все коллектаблы и прочий шлак. В игре есть нпс, подсказывающий оставшиеся секреты, а в конце игры вообще нужные локации начинают подсвечиваться, чтобы вы не терялись в этом огромном мире без карты. Единственный минус для таких людей - здесь есть достижения, которые можно по не знанию пропустить при первом прохождении, и далее по сюжету их получить не получится. Так что придется заводить новый сейв и проходить до нужного момента с самого начала.
В остальном же, это был просто потрясный экспириенс. Однозначно рекомендую к покупке!
10 лесных духов из 10.

There is a good base game here, but for everything that it does right it has a dozen things related to it that it does wrong. Issues range all the way from curious choices to absolutely annoying things that when collected together make this very annoying to play and not at all enjoyable - which is sad, because you can see the good base being destroyed by everything else.

It is also a short game at 12 hours to beat which includes a lot of dying because the only way I got through it without deleting it and never touching it again was to play while watching movies. Anyone who has issues with flashing things may want to avoid this, too. There is an option to turn off flashes, but it doesn't actually do anything ... which is how most of everything else in the game works also. Playing at night is great with screen flashes so bright birds outside think it's time to get up.

The art and the music are the only things I don't have anything bad to say about. The music was actually quite nice. Everything else shown in product videos is very cherry picked to show something happening the way it can in best case scenarios where none of the problems come into play.

Pros:

• Interesting story, feels very Legend of Zelda-like.

• Phenomenal soundtrack, really shines through during boss fights.
• Puzzles are enjoyable.

Cons:
• Only about 8-9 hrs to finish the game (or ~10 hrs if you're the type to comb through everything.)
• 𝙉𝙤 𝙙𝙞𝙛𝙛𝙞𝙘𝙪𝙡𝙩𝙮 𝙨𝙚𝙩𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜𝙨. This is a big one for me. Some bosses/areas feel like a cake walk. Leaves you going "Oh...that was it?" There's no penalty for dying either, and you can simply run past a lot of enemies.
• No minimap (or any map, for that matter.) Areas are like a labyrinth and it's easy to walk past an important room by accident. This can lead to a lot of backtracking. 
• Not much weapon/ability variety. All weapons feel very similar. Out of 4 abilities, the only one that felt enriching was the Hookshot. 

7/10, if they made a second one I'd probably still buy it.

139597447.review:
A very short, but also very charming little Souls-lite game. 

The gameplay itself is above average, resorting to a rather simple hack-n-slash system at first but does build it up a little bit more with magic and combos with light/heavy attacks, but it's not more than that. It's a solid enough system in it's right, but all other mechanics within that bucket are rather underutilized. Too with the different weapons and the upgrade system. I didn't really feel the upgrades in and of themselves did much to really spice anything up. Too with the weapons that - for being rather cool looking - didn't do much to really vary the gameplay. Honestly, you could very well stick with the starter sword for the whole game and feel little to no effect. The only one that has [i] some [/i] altercations to the way it works is the hammer with the shock attack and very long heavy attack windup but the others very much feel like typical "quick but low damage" and "slow but high damage" variations with no more thoughts to their design. Magic attacks too feel very much the same apart from the bomb which is hard to use in fights for it's slow charge.

Performance and graphics wise it is solid. Played it on my Steam Deck and had it play at a solid 60 fps with the APU at full load, which meant it could only play for 90 mins on full charge. But, in short, it looks well and will play well on just about any system.

Story is very confusing. The beginning and the "main hook" with your assigned soul being stolen and having to figure out how it ties in to the upheaval of the word to not spoil much. But honestly, I don't even how much I really [i] can [/i] spoil in this game. The midpoint of the story feels utterly nonsensical and it's only in the end it tries to take itself seriously about the whole prospect of death and what is sacrificed trying to reach immortality, but by that point it's too little too late for the game. 

The only thing I feel redeems it is the puzzle and platforming outside of it. It's well thought out and can be quite a mind tweezer trying to figure out how to move through an area and in that regard they do feel quite well designed and memorable so the lack of a map doesn't feel like a issue in the game. And the secrets inside of the game are also rather well thought out with the one caviat of the man-hole covers and NEVER being told you have a ground-pound attack you can do from the air to access them. I had to google that to figure out what their purpose was.

All in all... It's decent. It's a fine enough little time waster I'd say you should get on a sale if it interests you. Don't expect the world from it, but it's a fine enough little treat.

I'm basically stuck trying to beat the frog king and can't get any further. So now I'm stuck trying to upgrade my stats so I can do better against the frog king, but the only way to do that is to go back to earlier stages and defeat weaker enemies. But earlier enemies are few and far between, so I have to keep re-playing earlier stages over and over until I get enough soul points, which is really boring and annoying. It takes forever to build up enough soul points to upgrade your stats. I kind of want to quit this game entirely cause it's such a chore, but I also want to see the end of the story. I'd recommend not starting this game and getting sucked into the story like I did. If you're a casual fan of action RPGs, I recommend the Swords of Ditto, it's much more fun than this game.
