Death's Door is an all-around good experience, but leaves me wanting more.

It has the satisfying combat and variety. It has decent graphics and music that add up to an atmosphere that is greater than the sum of its parts. Finding all the secrets is in a perfect middle ground between trivial and infuriating. The world has character, though the characters are a little bland. And the bosses are great.

But there aren't many bosses. And there certainly aren't challenging bosses. I only got the health/ability upgrades after the first ending and going for 100%, hoping there'd be something more to stand up to my new found power afterwards - sadly, there was no such thing. Not even the optional boss [spoiler]and best character[/spoiler] provided more of a challenge than the final boss.

Nevertheless, I will recommend this title to those looking for a classic Legend of Zelda or Dark Souls casual alternative. It's very solid.

138079117.review:
[h1]The Legend of Z... Crow[/h1]
Death's Door is an unusual game, combining a Legend of Zelda style of exploration with Soulslike combat and a whiff of Grim Fandango's death-related humour. It has charm, memorable characters and fun boss battles. The generic enemies are not that special, but they are actually not annoying which is unusual.

There's an assortment of weapons, tons of shinies to collect and some pretty sweet environments to spend a chunk of your time on. It is a fun game to experience. One thing of note in fact is that each boss gets a eulogy and burial. And the final boss is not the end of the game... I personally also really dig the way they introduce the character Pothead, a definite nod to Siegward, Siegmeyer and Sieglinde from the Dark Souls trilogy.

If I have to voice some gripes though? The final boss' first battle is an obstacle course slog. Doable, but it drags on too much. And the umbrella challenge achievement does require you to not even swing your default weapon until you pick the darn thing up and switch to it. Some areas also have enemy spam with cheap death opportunities on top due to Crow being unable to swim or fly. Some more bosses or enemy types would've been nice to have.

All in all, I'd say Death's Door is well worth the money and time you need to put into it, but know that its a short game and not too challenging.

The thing I only knew in the last boss fight is that you can spam dodge to undo that one effect that locks you into place. so all the upgrade fights were really hard for me because I had to take 3 hits from those specific effects every fight. anyways, fun game, a little hard. But if you don't give up and be patient all the bosses are doable.

138040365.review: I actually really did love this game despite all the comments calling it mid. I found the bosses fun, the enemies interesting and the story intriguing. 138037593.review:
What a wonderful little game. The music, atmosphere, humour, visual design, level design, it's just so...*cozy* and just made me happy to play and experience. The story, writing and dialogue has made me feel both happy and sad, and made me laugh. Overall just a great game that I'm thoroughly enjoying.

Sometimes I wish it was more difficult, the combat and puzzles are pretty straightforward and not mechanically complex. Coming off of Hades, this definitely feels very..."basic" in comparison, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing - it's just going for something different. It's simple, but it does simple well and it's strengths are by far what I listed above. If you want a hardcore gaming experience this may not be for you.

Edit: I beat the game at around 8.5 hours. I can tell there's definitely a lot of extra secrets that I could go back and explore the world again, so that could probably extend gametime a bit. I won't because my backlog is too big for that. Some may feel like the price doesn't reflect that kind of length, but this game was pretty quality all the way through.

My biggest complaint after looking at the whole thing, is that the bosses. They were cool and had great themes, but usually repeated the exact same 2, maybe 3 attack patterns over and over again which weren't all that difficult to read. The difficulty with them came usually at the extent of how many hits you had to land and sometimes felt very spongy - so sometimes I found myself getting a bit bored because I "got" the boss but had to sit through the same 2-3 attacks for a while before they were beat. I feel like I would have gotten all the bosses on the first attempt, but usually because of how spongy they were I got too greedy and would get punished and die. I wish I would die from having to learn the boss, as opposed to struggle with greed. The visual design and setpiecing of them though I feel makes up for that. 

I feel overall after finishing that I can recommend those who want a cozy, zelda like explorative experience with great atmosphere and setpiecing. If you want a gaming challenge, this isn't it.

Sorry, but despite wanting to play this story out; I have plenty of other games to play. Reaching new areas and enjoying my time spent is FAR more important than re-tracing the same outline of a game over and over.

137868511.review:
Played through it twice, once for 100% and once to clean up the rest of the achievements.

In terms of audio and visual production value, it's good. Mechanically, it's fine, if somewhat on the easy side. But it starts in an interesting and story-forward way with an intense ambiance and an interesting premise, and then just drops more and more of that story on the floor as the game goes on. By the end of the postgame, the final narrative sequence is mostly about a different game entirely, while leaving every narrative question I was actually interested in completely unanswered. 

It probably feels harsh to give a negative review to a game that plays perfectly well just because of its approach to storytelling, but it's hard for me to exaggerate the extent to which that storytelling peaks in the first five minutes and goes continuously downhill from there. At the start of the game, everything about the character's role and their motivation for pursuing the game's objectives make sense in light of in-game events. But by midgame, you're just wading through trite non-sequitur video-game-isms that go unexplained and unacknowledged by all the narrative parts of the setting (e.g. the best non-spoilery example I can think of: every dungeon eventually teleports you back to a remote area of your headquarters where a crowned ghost-bird locked in a box grants you a new spell after an internal battle. It's a very video-game-y mechanic, but [i]why[/i]? Who're these birds? Crowns are a meaningful symbol, so why a crown? What's the link to your organization? Were these spells locked and hidden to keep them from people like you; if so, when and by whom? These details would fit perfectly well in the story and add appropriate complication... but instead, nothing and nobody else ever mentions them or expresses any interest in them, so they're just a wild out-of-the-blue mechanic and animation that turns the game farther toward no-context generic-fantasy. If there's going to be no tie-in to the rest of the game at all, it would be better if they were just items in a box without fanfare; having an elaborate visual spectacle with no meaning just makes it clearer that the game doesn't care about the [i]why[/i] of things anymore, and neither should you.) Postgame continues right off the deep end; video game logic rises to 100%, narrative justification falls to 0%, and a convoluted fetch-quest culminates in a cutscene that's mostly about a different game entirely (that game was fine; I'm not sure why its protagonist needed to take narrative splash-damage from the 'true ending' of this one).

So ultimately this review is dedicated to the escalating sense of disappointment I felt as each development in this game's story managed to further undercut the initial interest it piqued. [spoiler]Death winking at the camera[/spoiler], this is for you.

The way the game is presented feels unimpactful and empty; all the encounters just blend into one another, nothing ever feels like anything different is happening. Lots of running around and pulling levers. 

Style is good, music is nice, some fun characters and dialogue / situations that made me laugh a bit, but those enjoyable moments are too sparse. In between them is just samey lever pulling forever. The environment design is good looking but it's just used to facilitate straightforward basic level design without any depth and barely any variation besides a few slightly different ways to activate a door opening, and 90% of your time will be spent just running around finding switches to open doors so that you can open more doors in the same way. 

It's ok overall. If you just want to run around in a cool looking place and see some neat characters, you can enjoy this game. But don't expect it to surprise / wow you or have much of a narrative impact. 

Thumbs down not because it's completely bad, but just because I can't actually get behind recommending it. I got it in a bundle with Inscryption which I loved, so I decided to try this one out, but I honestly wouldn't feel good about telling most people to straight up buy it individually. 136485590.review:
Death's Door is an isometric metroidvania-esc game that's worth playing and experiencing, albeit with some issues. 

If you enjoyed playing Hyper Light Drifter, you'll easily scratch a similar itch here. This game revolves around going to different areas and defeating bosses after solving puzzles/clearing rooms, unlocking collectibles and new areas as you gain your 4 primary spells.

The game looks amazing and the controls are super responsive. You can tell the developers really cared about the game and poured in a lot of passion. The music is great, although it didn't stick with me as well as other game soundtracks. The use of leitmotifs was fun, and the music often fit their settings, but for some reason I don't see myself listening to the soundtrack outside of the game as much as I would with others. Originally, I felt that the music seemed repetitive at first because it definitely was - at least, before you get moving to other areas. As the game opened up more and more, that became much less of an issue and I found myself enjoying the soundtrack more.

As for story, the game definitely feels like it falls a bit short there. There are some great set pieces and a very intriguing world that is built, with some charming but one note characters. It almost felt like they had a vague idea on what they wanted to say, but the gameplay doesn't exactly lend itself to the story it's trying to tell, and otherwise characters show up maybe once or twice throughout the whole game for specific plot points and aren't relevant otherwise.

As for the combat, this ties into the game's controls and I'd say that they feel really good to use. Your attacks are quick and there's great feedback from each hit, especially if you're playing on controller and have some rumble enabled. However I do agree with a common critic of the combat - it's a bit repetitive. While the combat feels good, many combat encounters become a test of stamina. How many waves of enemies can you fend off back to back? 

I wouldn't say that it's necessarily not fun, I found myself enjoying dodging around while I kited enemies, deflected shots back at them while weaving in and out. The boss encounters are a bit challenging but once you get their patterns down, it's really satisfying to dodge in and out to get some hits in when you can. But if the combat isn't initially engaging for you, you may find yourself having a difficult time playing through the rest of the game because it's basically more of that. While there are different weapons to unlock throughout your playthrough, I found myself enjoying the default sword the most, and I didn't exactly feel a lot of variation in the combat even as you unlocked new weapons and spells.

The spells are more important for exploration than combat, too. They do have upgrades that you can get through finding challenge arenas throughout the world, but their upgrades feel almost like quality of life improvements than substantial power boosts. Again, if you don't exactly like how a spell feels, you're likely not going to like it much more after getting it's upgrade.

Another point of contention I had when I was playing through the game was that the lack of a map of any kind made navigating the world a bit more convoluted than I would have liked. Eventually, you get your feel for the areas, but on your first couple of times through, you end up just stumbling around and getting confused as to which room leads where. I would have also enjoyed a bit more indication as to what and where things you may have missed in an area are. As I was trying to 100% the game, I found myself running through areas I had already cleared over and over again, unsure of what to even look for while the game told me something was still left to be found. 

An indication of just what I'm missing from an area would have been appreciated. At the same time, towards the end of the game, there are unlockables that cannot be accessed until you do something in a different area, leading to moments where I ran through an area checking everything, wasting time trying to find what I missed before realizing that completing a different area first would allow me to access what I was missing. I'm not sure as to if there's an elegant solution to this issue, but I wish it didn't feel like there was time being wasted that I didn't need to waste.

Even with all of these critiques, I'd still highly recommend this game. For the price, you're getting a well rounded package that I still greatly enjoyed playing. While it doesn't break any new ground like some other games that send me to annoy and pester all my friends to play it, it doesn't exactly have to. If this game seems interesting to you, I can reasonably say that you'll likely enjoy your time with it. It's got some areas that need more refinement to truly make the experience smooth, but I definitely had a nice time playing through the game. (I mean, I wouldn't have 100% the game if I didn't like it!)

136482835.review:

136430657.review:
Una primera reseña, basada en mis apenas cuatro horas jugadas por ahora, le daría el imprescindible para cualquier fan de los metroidvania. Es un juego muy orgánico, que tiene lo mejor de un Souls desde el punto de vista de descubrir secretos, atajos y lore del juego, mezclado con un juego de puzles que, sin ser demasiado desafiante, deja en ocasiones ese regusto tan agradable del descubrimiento de algo por uno mismo. El estilo estético no sabría definirlo pero se ve claramente diferente de los formatos más típicos de este subgénero de videojuego, que suelen tirar por lo pixel art o lo cartoon. La música es genial, de hecho el tema principal del juego es una maravilla para ponerse en bucle mientras trabajas, estudias o haces cualquier tarea (Dato random pero que yo suelo valorar mucho). Respecto al combate repito la (manida) comparativa con un Souls. ¿Es desafiante? Sí, si vas como potro desbocao. ¿Es frustrante?  Para nada, sobre todo si observas al enemigo y cuidas una estrategia mínima. La perspectiva del juego, la vista, que no termina de ser del todo cenital pero no es la clásica para un juego en 3D tampoco, sería más bien un híbrido, es algo bastante interesante por la novedad aunque puede hacer que se te envenene algún combate más de la cuenta. La historia y los diálogos por ahora me han parecido bastante más graciosos de lo que esperaba (también depende del nivel de humor que tengas, hay que admitirlo). Como cosa negativa, algunas mecánicas no terminan de quedar claras si no estás muy atento, por ejemplo, tuve que acudir a comentarios de los propios desarrolladores y otros usuarios respecto al funcionamiento de los checkpoints que, aunque estaban en mi cara en algunos momentos, no había entendido bien como funcionaban. 

En fin, buena chapa para haber jugado solo 4h, pero el juego me está encantando. Si te mola el género metroidvania este juego, personalmente, debe ser un must.

136380540.review: Is the game bad?  No, but it is so aggressively mediocre.  For all it's peers within the genre, it has very little that makes it stick out aside from maybe the theme.  All the weapons hit in the same arc and the only variance across them is VERY minor stat differences.  Like the normal weapon has an attack value of 1, and the big hammer has a damage value of 1.2 which makes it pointless since it only can attack twice between swings.  The daggers are objectively the best weapon in the game since the attack value is .8 but can attack six times in a volley (and also has the fastest attack speed).  The enemy variety is very low, and combat gets repetitive pretty fast.  I will say that the final fight was the most interesting part of the game.  The rest is just so, bland and boring.  I played Tunic a few months ago, and that puts this game to shame in every single department.

136322542.review:
Made by the creators of Titan Souls, a game I have quite a connection to (and by that I mean I played the game once, beat a few bosses, understood how the formula works and dropped it never to pick it again). 
 Death's Door is, in its core a simple metroidvania, and it works very well with that. It has simple artstyle, simple enemies, and simple mechanics. if it was all that however, I wouldn't say it is simply good, the game has amazing characters, incredibly good bosses with readable movesets, and banger OST.
 It's core problem comes with location designs, or as I would call them "goddamn mazes" and the amount of walking and backtracking in this game is beyond tedious. The game is also very linear, it tries to hide it by giving names of certain bosses you have to beat, but you only can access one, and the others are locked behind obstructions that can only be cleared by getting the ability in the area of the first boss. And with locations having collectibles locked behind gaining the abilities from other bosses areas it gets annoying. With the best idea to get all the collectibles you journey would have to go like this: 1. Go to the boss location 1 and get ability 2. backtrack and go get to the boss location 2 ability  3. repeat steps 1 to 2 until you get all abilities. Then finally you have the freedom to go all around and then start killing bosses in whatever order you want. Although all that criticisms I still enjoyed the game very much, the collectibles in particular are very purposeful, they are either objects with lore in them, or souls which you can use for upgrades. With that in mind I will say the game is incredibly fair. Not once when dying I felt that it was the game's fault. With all that in mind, I can recommend this game to anybody that wants some easy metroidvania on one or two nights.
Getting to the true ending was time-eating and completely unfun tho. I wouldnt recommend doing that.

136066657.review:
Not an easy thing to "not recommend" it's very pretty and has a nice coherent fun story.

But I just can't recommend it. The game is shockingly long for the content within. The purchaseable upgrades aren't fun or interesting. The upgrades to health and magic are very hard to find without spending absurd amounts of time. I never bothered to find an upgrade to a single spell because it involves painstaking backtracking in the very late game and every hidden item outside the weapons wasn't worth the effort invested up to that point. I didn't even know they existed until I looked up the achievements. (Don't even get me started on the extremely time-intensive un-fun achievements).

The combat is also pretty unrewarding, you have no way of healing and a small pool of health mistakes. The dodge roll feels floaty and you have to trigger it early, but some bosses and enemies are specifically built to punish too-early dodges. It's mostly just frustrating. At least the final boss fight has checkpoints, but they're pretty darn far apart.

My recommendation is probably to watch a stream of it, it'll be a more enjoyable experience. Unless you can get it ultra cheap.

136037381.review:
hey guys just here to say that I managed to play this for 4 hours without pressing the actual attack button because there is a separate button for slow ass charge attacks that I thought was the only attack in the game

world, writing, music, atmosphere, boss design: amazing, chef's kiss. It's an interesting world and has a really great sense of humour, I loved poking around everywhere for more lore and dialogue. There's all these subtle touches that made me laugh. 

It's a small thing, but the sound effect when going through dialogue boxes is the most satisfying thing in the world. Whoever implemented that deserves an award. The music that plays when you give each boss a little funeral is also so melancholy yet has this gentle levity to it that matches the dialogue as well.. They really nailed the tone for this game. SSSS+ tier. 

combat: it's alright, upgrading and finding new weapons is fun. I find it on the difficult side though, and very punishing how little health you have. I loved the writing in this game so much that I wished it was some kind of exploration focused RPG instead honestly. I just wanted to talk to NPCs because their dialogue was such a treat (and I was thirsty for the dialogue box ASMR I guess). The combat is serviceable but it's just kinda there (outside of the cool boss fights).

level design: as someone who has 0 sense of direction, this is HELL. The maps seems to be designed to be as confusing as possible, especially when forced to backtrack. Everything is some circular maze so it's painful to find the one little switch or ladder you haven't pressed, and there's not enough landmarks to get a sense of direction. 

It's a shame the gameplay (and navigation) is too punishing because aesthetically this game is wonderful and I love everything about it narratively. I'm in disbelief that this game was made by two people. 

Also in the post game you can go on a date with a squid. 10/10

135943995.review:
Okay, so initally I bounced off this game really hard pretty early at a specific miniboss. I decided to give the game a second chance and I'm glad I did. While I still have some complaints (especially about that miniboss), and I'll go into them, I enjoyed the game thoroughly and 100%-ed it.

First, the good. Although I have some issues with it, the gameplay overall is incredibly solid. Combat is fun and just feels good about 95% of the time, and exploration is interesting and fairly rewarding. The game is beautiful, although the relatively limited color palette does start to feel slightly stale by the end of the game. The music is really good, especially the high intensity tracks. The writing is also a standout, and is legitimately hilarious at times.

Now for the negatives. There's a few mechanical issues that can get frustrating. Most of the magic/ranged abilities have autoaim, which is usually good, but sometimes will aim at the wrong thing, or in the case of the last magic ability, miss entirely. It's usually not an issue, but there's some portions where you need to cast quickly and accurately, so it can get a bit frustrating at those times. Works well most of the time though.

I mentioned a miniboss that made me quit the first time I tried. The huge mace guys are, by far, the worst enemies in the game, and they appear about a half dozen times. The main issue with them is the way hitboxes in this game work. They are much larger than they appear visually, especially for ground AOEs (which is all the mace guys do). Now, normally, this is countered by the i-frames from your dodge roll. You just ignore where the AOE is hitting and dodge right before it hits, no problem. I don't particularly like the design of it, but it's functional. The issue comes with the mace guys doing 2-3 ground slams in rapid succesion. I frequently found myself dodging away from them, avoiding the first attack, only to still be in range of the second attack before my dodge roll came off cooldown. It was infuriating.

These enemies do become easier to deal with as you either upgrade attack, which gives you better range, or find one of the two weapons with better range. This lets you poke at them from the edge of their range and dodge away. It's not fun, but it's doable at least. I really wish these fights were better, though, because basically all the other minibosses and bosses are super fun to fight.

Finally, some nitpicks. The game is a bit labyrinthine, so it can be hard to be sure you've explored everywhere. Thankfully, areas aren't too large, so it's not as much of a problem as it could be. Also, and this is just a personal issue, you can't 100% the game before the final boss. You can get almost to 90%, but the last 10% or so is only available in the postgame. Just a warning for folks like me to like to complete everything before the end boss.

Still, even with these complaints, the game is very good, and I definitely don't regret giving it a second chance. I don't think I'll be doing the umbrella challenge anytime soon, but I certainly had fun with my playthrough.

135288589.review: Death's Door is a flawed but wonderful game. Sound and music? Perfect. Visual design? Beautiful. Combat? Fluid. But here's where things get iffy.[olist][*]Firstly, the WHOLE game is painfully linear. From start to finish, you travel in one long winding path that just happens to intersect back on itself sometimes, giving the illusion of these big, sprawling, complex landscapes. And no, I don't mean this in the way that zelda-likes or metroidvanias require looping back on themselves. What we have here is a whole lot worse.[*]Secondly, exploration is shallow. Along this linear path, you can stray from it here and there, and you'll often be rewarded for doing so, but it's always just that: the reward, which is always very minor. You won't find large hidden areas or secret paths or hidden abilities.[*]Thirdly, items, weapons and abilities. Yes, you unlock a few abilities that spice up combat and allow you to go back and pick up stuff you couldn't earlier, but there's nothing more than that. There are weapons to collect, but they lack diversity and balance, making only a couple have any use. There are items to collect, maybe like 25 or 30, but out of all of them, I can only think of 1 that had any use at all. The rest were purely for the sake of having.[*]Fourth, puzzles. Every puzzle in the game except maybe 1 is self-contained. Meaning if you have the tools to solve it, you don't need to leave the room to complete it. This makes puzzlesolving uninteresting and way too easy, at least for me.[*]Fifth, worldbuilding. Any depth that was added to this world is only conveyed to you [spoiler]at the end of the game. And there isn't really a whole lot of depth to be conveyed at all.[/spoiler][*]Lastly,[spoiler] the endgame. You set out to collect the MacGuffins, which requires a lot of backtracking, and along the way, the number of new enemies that you encounter could be counted on less than half of one hand. And once you collect 'em all, there's... (MAJOR SPOILERS----->) nothing. Not even a boss. Just lore, and at that point I hardly cared very much.[/spoiler][/olist]TL;DR:[list][*]Sound, music, visual design, and combat are very good[*]The game is linear[*]Exploration is shallow[*]Collecting things has very little value[*]Puzzles are dull and too easy[*]Worldbuilding is close to nonexistent outside of a few cutscenes[*][spoiler]The endgame is very close to pointless[/spoiler][/list]

Very fun little action adventure game that makes up for its short length with some very polished and balanced design:
[list]
[*]Challenging enough to add some excitement and easy enough to be generally relaxing to play. 
[*]Fun, quick-paced combat with a kit versatile enough to keep things feeling fresh for the duration.
[*]A charming story with unexpected depth and gentleness towards the universality of death and loss.
[*]World design complex enough to require some creative thinking while simple enough to not get tedious.
[*]A reasonable number of collectibles that add a little extra post-clear content with enough hints to avoid having to look things up online.

[/list]
It also has a really solid soundtrack. Check it out!

135009595.review:
Like so many others, wish I could do a mid-thumb/maybe. I had fun in this game, at least until the first boss fell. It's like a softer Zelda-esque game, complete with the "darkworld" when you can finally get to it. The opening stuff was fun and the first boss was even fun. I liked her house and the way she would show up periodically. There was even a fun new character to meet. The second boss and third boss left much to be desired, the latter not even showing up until the fight. Maybe give me a map too? Jeez. Sometimes those layers of areas were maddening to try and memorize where I needed one specific thing, particularly with the ghosts.

This is pretty much the summary of the whole game. Three bosses, final boss, then extra stuff if you want to 100% the game. The combat was fluid, but became tedious and boring. Bosses all had the same timing for dodges. You just picked the weapon you liked best and could capitalize on it's strength/speed. The achievements weren't even one of the parts of the game that made it fun. After running around for close to 4-5 hours finding shrines, I just gave up on the 100%. The music was very pleasant but the scenery was very melancholy. I understand that was probably the intent but still made it difficult to look forward to beating the game. Maybe change the world a little when a boss was beaten? This last bit will just be left open, since it's a spoiler to discuss it further. The story was "interesting", I guess. Glad that it was only like 12 hours long, which is about all you need to beat the game without feeling too much of a grind.

TL:DR-Music was nice. Battles became tedious. Story was okay. I'd give it 7.5/10.

This game is, regarding the manual dexterity it requires to defeat certain bosses, simply too difficult for some to play. I just couldn't do it, and believe me, I tried. I tried hard. But dying again and again and again and having to take a long labyrintine walk back to those bosses each time is insanely frustrating. It took all fun out of the game. Thus I stopped playing it at all.

The developers simply forgot or ignored, that not all players have the same skill, that not all own game controllers and that not all players expect the same experience regarding difficulty. I just wanted a fun experience exploring the admittedly great, atmospheric world of this game, but didn't get my moneys worth of that, because after a certain point it was humanly impossible for me to get any further.

I am willing to reconsider this review if there's ever a an easy mode added to the game, because until then only very skilled hard core gamers will get to enjoy the entirety of it.

Я купив гру бо мені сподобався трейлер і стилістика, вона хоч і проста, але добре пропрацьована.
Проте дуже швидко стає зрозумілим головний мінус гри - це геймплей. Він однообразний і нудний.
Всю гру ви будете використовувати одні й ті ж атаки. Майже вся зброя відчувається однаково за виключенням клинків (але їх треба знайти). 

Битви з другорядними босами або арени для здобуття магічних здібностей теж доволі одноманітні.
Головні боси гри зроблені непогано, починаючи з Йеті вони вимагають запам'ятати механіки боса і багато спроб.

Проте гру дуже псують купа дрібних геймплейних моментів які просто дратують. Це левел дизайн, чекпоінти, неможливість перезапустити битву з босом, тощо.

Мій загальний вердикт грі - вона ніяка. Не можна сказати, що вона дуже погана, але і доброю її не назвеш.

From things like sewer runs from Mario Sunshine, to puzzle dungeons like some Ocarina of Time. The combat is fresh and clean with a good amount of depth. The art and humour are quirky with some added wit. Some of the philosophy of this game reflects Eastern thought like Buddhism with concepts like reincarnation (souls being recycled), or of Hinduism's Brahman (from quotes like "the universe experiences itself"). Pretty interesting game overall, the seeds which are scattered throughout the game are required to all be collected for a 100% but I was able to organically collect 48 of them on my first playthrough without overthinking it. You would probably need to complete this game a second time for all the achievements unless you set out to collect them from the start.

132271572.review:
Death’s Door

You are a crow working for the reaper commission, tasked with reaping your designated soul. Something goes awry after defeating your target and you lose the soul you have to deliver to the headquarters. Reapers usually can’t die as long as they do their job properly. As you have lost the soul, you are now not immortal and have to get it back. On your journey you have to travel to 3 distinct areas to defeat three big beings to reap their giant souls. According to a big old crow, who stole your soul, in order to open the so called Death’s Door the 3 giant souls are required to gain access to you target’s soul again.

While traveling the different areas the crow will face puzzles and battles, both which are not too hard but not easy either. The combat is good to understand, not too shallow but also not too complex so that you can quite enjoy it. Depending on the weapon you have a different range, can attack multiple times, charge attack and dodge attack. You will learn multiple spells to fight and deal with certain obstacles. There is an upgrade system you can access in the reaping headquarters. Basically you can level 4 different aspects (melee damage, magic damage, faster attacking/charging, more speed/better dodge roll), though each upgrade is fairly minor and costs more and more soul energy gained by slaying enemies or found in the world.

The areas itself are most of the time rather linear. In each area is one dungeon with a big locked door. Each time you have to gather the souls of 4 deceased crows to get enough energy to open the door and get a new spell to advance further. The concept is a bit too formulaic but each dungeon is very different to each other nonetheless so it doesn’t matter that much. While being more linear there is still much to explore. Hidden doors, secret passages, places in previous areas which are now accessible, there is a lot to find. Sometimes the game plays with its perspective to conceal secrets, for example you walk to a corner of a wall just so that the camera shifts and reveals a secret area there. Most of the stuff you find is just soul energy used to upgrade your stats or life seeds which are needed to grow healing plants in pots spread around the world. A few weapons are scattered around the world, each feeling different in battle and usable in one way or the other. Though I did not use one weapon in particular because I was enjoying another weapon I found prior and latter got a weapon better altogether.
Sometimes you find some shiny trinkets which, besides a steam achievement and 2 used ingame for something, are mostly just for lore/fluff which yeah is fair, but don't expect something like “Ohhhh what a cool item I found, I wonder what it could be used for”. Occasionally you will also find secret shrines which increase your health or magic pool when getting 4 of the respective kind.

The artstyle is awesome. Death’s Door has a great and coherent look. The character designs are akin to some of the big animation studios some say comparable to Ghibli. Each area has a distinctive look. The Reaping Headquarters for example is almost fully grey with certain few objects giving a distinguished color.

The soundtrack by David Fenn is just beautiful. Each area has a great atmospheric soundtrack. I couldn’t help myself but humming to the melody from time to time. Calm soothing tracks are followed by adventurous ones, some emphasising the urgency of your current situation, we even got some battle songs with a rather rocky guitar touch. All songs are fitting neatly together. Some have a recurring melody with a different arrangement/instruments/added parts which is really cool, especially when the melody came back in a guitar boss battle theme. The whole ost is available on YouTube if you want to listen to it before making a decision. Just let me say that alone for the ost the game is more than worth it.

I like everything of the game, the gameplay, the artstyle, the music, the story, you name it.
It is a highly recommendable game for me. If you liked what you read consider buying it.

132023624.review:
[h1] Squawking Good Time [/h1]

[b]| [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vMqmg0LwlTc]Click here for the Video Review[/url] |[b]

[b]| Intro |[/b]
Death's Door is a prime example of pairing simplicity with diversity. The dungeon-crawling, souls-style game creates an interesting, enjoyable, and more welcoming title in the genre. As a *sword*-wielding, *projectile*-flinging, *soul*-stealing, acrobatic-avian, you have everything you need to explore the vast and intricate environments on your quest. Victories feel rewarding, deaths make you want to give it another go.

[b]| Combat |[/b]
[i]Dying is quick, Getting back to the fight is quicker[/i]
Due to being a tiny bird, you are required to be crafty, quick, and precise to effectively cut through the demonic creatures that fill the land. The simple, yet effective combat techniques at your disposal are more than enough when facing the unique enemies and bosses that you will encounter. Death's Door may not delve as deep into various battle-styles, but this isn't without purpose as every fight feels unique and fresh due scenery, terrain, and opponent match-ups. Some fights are easier than others, but there are definitely multiple fights that end with [b] DEATH [/b] appearing on your screen in giant letters. Every death is quickly greeted with life and another chance to battle. There wasn't a single time that I felt frustrated in the presence of death, [i] even in a particular fight that cost me my life 20+ times [/i]. Almost every death had me going "Yeah, I messed up there". Die, Learn, Repeat until you don't die. 

[b]| Gameplay |[/b]
[i]Shiny stuff... shiny stuff everywhere![/i]
Death's Door drops you into an environment that feels devastated, decayed, and abandoned. As you travel to multiple areas, you will find yourself dissecting every possible section to find any hidden secrets. You will be left wondering what happened here and why isn't anyone talking about it. There is a constant crave to find secret passageways, solve puzzles, and gather items as you advance forward. Death's Door is a trifecta, combining Zelda-Souls-Metroidvania aspects, all into one game. You are rewarded for exploration, but make sure you are always aware of where you are. One thing to note, you are not equipped with a map to navigate, resulting in a few minutes of backtracking and going through a couple of doors until you find your way. It fits the theme, but I wish my little crow had a better understanding of his surroundings.

[b]| Sound |[/b]
[i]Squawking in Harmony[/i]
Death's Door wouldn't be complete without its upbeat, electric-orchestral mix to aid you in your epic quest and intense fights. You might find yourself experiencing the battle theme over and over again due to [b]DEATH[/b], but you will be head-bopping the entire time. Your attacks are satisfying, from swift swooshes to heavy thonks. Occasionally, I found my audio volume adjusting mid-game to either very loud or very soft. I'm not sure what the cause of this was, but ultimately, it didn't take away from the experience.

[b]| Conclusion |[/b]
All in All, Death's Door was enjoyable and intense. It's welcoming to players who might not be willing to fight through Elden Ring, but still challenging enough that most people will die a few times :) If you are okay with that, then I would absolutely recommend Death's Door. You can currently pick up the game for $20, which I truly believe is an absolute steal. I still have the post-game content to complete, but I couldn't wait to get my thoughts out about Death's Door. I'm hoping that Acid Nerve is working on a sequel as you will find me first in line for it.

131971770.review:
Ah, this was a great time. It's a short game, but that lends itself well to the extremely tight execution. The narrative is equal parts whimsical and bleak, with a sort of Hollow Knight/Dark Souls energy that is currently trendy, but not yet over-done, and memorable characters and locations. The over-world hub is really intriguing as well, and I love the choice to only render certain things in color. And the music is beautiful!

But where the game really shines is in the game-play: namely, platforming, puzzles, and combat. The progression of platforming is really satisfying, giving you just enough "roadblocks" to make you realize you're probably going to need a new skill for that, and not to waste your time without it. As you gain skills, it really opens up the game, and it gives that good good dopamine. Puzzles are clever, though rarely difficult enough to really slow your progress, and flow nicely with the rest of the game. Combat is the true star here, offering an enjoyable level of difficulty and a learning curve that makes you feel like a god when you get into the groove. It requires you to learn each enemy's movements and attack patterns: when is it safe to swing at them? Once, twice, three times? When they curl up, they're going to roll at you! Dodge them, but not right away, or else they'll re-align to hit you as you come out of the dodge roll. Satisfying, frustrating, and absolutely blissful when you get it right :)

My two points of criticism are these:
1) WHY NO MAP!? Dear God, WHY no MAP?
2) F the tongue dude

131675175.review:
It is a good game, the story was nice and I definitely did not expect the rue ending, I was surprised but I liked it.

The enemies in this game have very similar designs and that is not a bad thing, the game does not require a needlessly inflated enemy count. 

The reason can possibly be that the game is meant to be enjoyed mainly for its story and shouldn't be dragged out too long. I say that because I completed the game 100% in 8 hours and not once was it boring (maybe because I also enjoy finding everything). 

The main enemies can be broken down to 7 types: the lights, the grunts, the archers, the casters, the heavies, the minibosses and the bosses. Other than the bosses, which is obvious that they have different attacks, each enemy type has variations I'd say a minimum of 2 and a maximum 4 or 5 with each variation becoming more difficult to deal with. 

The combat has hit a sweet spot where it is fun, fluid and not insanely challenging, letting players at almost every skill range enjoy the experience. Basically once you get used to it you can take on everything the game throws at you as long as you can learn their attack patterns and get used to the dodge frames and distance.

There is some backtracking if you are looking to unlock hidden abilities and upgrade your character as much as you can, but it is not necessary and to be fair every area seems quite small once you clear it out and come back stronger.

131656535.review:
The line between this game and Tunic are very fitting.  Both games are isometric action adventure titles that take direct influences from NES+SNES Zelda and Souls-like games.  Both games have a degree of difficulty, especially with regard to bosses.  However, where Tunic spends its endgame in puzzles, Death's Door seems to spend its entirety in fighting and meeting characters.  

And for that, this reminds me a lot more of TLoZ: Ocarina of Time.  There's plenty of memories here that are just going to stay with you, nifty characters that will either hit or miss.  Also like Ocarina, the story beats are far better delivered than the story itself.  Some bosses were the life of the show for the entire dungeon, and some just kinda show up and I must've missed a dialog somewhere on why I should've cared who they were.  You'll often return to your home base expecting to hear new dialog from your friend-crows, but they're repeating what they've been saying since the previous dungeon.  Heck, by the end-game, when your friend-crows are mounting their rally cries, you've largely forgotten their names... they're just "crow who types" and "crow who smokes"

The tone varies wildly from serious to screwball and I think that can play against a game that should've been more earnest at times.  Your crowtagonist has great characterization for a mute protagonist, but this game just keeps kicking them around as if they didn't just wade through an army of pouncing zombies.  More than a few scenes are just played for cheap laughs when you really just want to see your crow and their friends go through a character arc

In the end, I really love this game, and any complaints are because I want to see a sequel really nail what this missed.  

The crow must be protected from death at all costs!

131498207.review:
If I could give a detailed review or at least a rating, I would say 7.5 out of 10. This game has a really solid foundation, but has some design choices that make me scratch my head. Lacking a map makes exploration and backtracking (which there is a lot of in this game) more tedious. Lacking a targeting reticle for ranged abilities makes combat and puzzles feel clunkier. In fact, while we're at it, why do I have to hold the trigger and press a button to activate a ranged ability? This game isn't exactly showering us with different actions (you can dodge, attack, interact, and charge attack). Why can't spells be their own buttons? Or at least cast on the move? That would have made combat feel far more dynamic, and less like it was punishing me for trying to weave spells in (each has a rather long charge up before use too, making melee really the only option in many fights and boss fights). 

And the final boss fight is far too long. Just way too drawn out for a character that we've basically only seen once. The penultimate boss fight should have been the end of the game.

Ultimately, this game is fun, and especially considering it's an indie and considering the price, I do recommend it.

This was just a joy to play through. The game is just pure fun. The combat is simple but can be challenging in many encounters and you need to pay attention to every enemy attack and don't underestimate anything. The world design is great, and the dungeons were all very well designed with a good balance of combat and the puzzles. Opening shortcuts in this was very satisfying and rewarding, and the presentation was also eye candy. Boss fights are good though nothing special. 


If I have to fault the game for anything, it'll probably be the exploration. Yeah, the game had side paths and secrets to discover, but unfortunately most of them were pretty useless. Most of the things you find aren't helpful in side quests or anything and are just collectibles which makes the exploration kinda unrewarding for you to seek it. I think they missed an opportunity, these objects might have had a purpose in small side quests to get additional rewards. Kinda shame.


But this is a small issue in an otherwise really good game. The combat, dungeons design and the overall feeling of the game, are all pure fun. It offers a solid amount of content for such game, finished it in 10 hours.

Worth it, get it during any near sale.

Overall, Death's Door is an excellent game. Every pixel is gorgeous, and the combat/gameplay are top notch. Anyone who is a fan of the Zelda franchise would adore this game. 

My main complaint is the need to plant EVERY SEED in EVERY POT in the game to get the alternate ending. Using a seed in a pot refills your health. Thus, I felt NOT using a pot to save a seed was a strategical choice - until the end of the game when I realized that I needed to go back and find every pot and seed to get the secret ending. Every other aspect of getting the alternate ending is like new little adventure - except planting every seed in every pot.  It felt like a huge chore. 

My only other complaint is - the lack of any type of map makes a lot of the traversing rather confusing. Although I get that having a map would possibly spoil some of the secrets.

131158025.review:
I'm quite torn on Death's door. 

There's elements I really like such as the great music,  gorgeous aesthetics, interesting characters, surprisingly good boss fights and the sheer amount of well hidden secrets.

While the boss fights are good the combat itself is a bit poor.  It isn't so bad that it ruins the experience but it just isn't particularly good either.

What does somewhat drag the experience down is the level design and the choice to not include a map.  I'm all for making the player explore the environment, the problem is that some of the areas are multi level mazes made up of similar looking rooms.  There were a few times during my 1st play-through that I got lost running in circles trying to find the last soul to progress.

That said I do recommend it, the positives heavily outweigh the negatives, clearly a lot of good work went into the game and it's definitely worth experiencing.

131010984.review:
When I first saw this game during a video game livestream, I thought to myself "Oh wow, a new roguelike I can sink hundreds of hours into!" That was until shortly after I found out that it wasn't gonna be a roguelike. It was an action adventure RPG. As someone who grew up solely on Call of Duty and a random assortment of Wii games, I really wasn't interested in single-player story driven games. Risk of Rain 2 was the only game I was really into at the time and I was craving for another game like it. But, I still wanted to give another indie dev a shot at wowing me. After all, these were the same devs that made Titan Souls and I thought the idea of killing boss after boss was cool. So I bought it.

The game and its world pulled me instantly. Its gameplay, music, and the little world that it had built was fantastic. The story revolves around life and death in a lighthearted way. Throwing little bits of humor and quirkiness for the player to breathe in and enjoy. I could really feel for the characters and their role in the grander story. There was no other game that I've played that was just like it. Death's Door's story can get kinda deep and emotional which are juxtaposed with the frantic combat of the game (That's not to say that it's bad, It's really fun and paired with its excellent story it works amazingly). I think that is why it was able to pull me in so well. And to some people these qualities may push you away from trying it yourself and that's okay. I just ask that you please give it a chance if you're slightly interested. 

It's a dear little game that holds a special place in my heart. Don't let it turn you down from playing it like it almost did to me. Give it a chance and enjoy yourself.

130548002.review:
A very good little Zelda clone, with some very, -very- light RPG elements. You play as a lil' crow running around trying to collect the 3 magical macguffins to get to the final boss. It has everything you'd expect for the genre: overworld / hub to railroad you to the 3 themed areas in appropriate order, light puzzling and combat to unlock the boss dungeon, new item to use as a puzzle gimmick for part 2 of the dungeon, then boss. It doesn't reinvent the wheel, but that's ok. The RPG elements are nice, and you can upgrade your character at a pretty decent pace, but the upgrades point-to-point don't feel terribly impactful. The controls are tight and responsive, iframes on your roll are very generous, and the enemies generally telegraph pretty well. The difficulty is quite low, but there's a mild spike for the final boss. There are no difficulty options aside from self-imposed challenge runs (namely, an achievement for beating the game with a weapon which deals 1/2 damage).

The art style is cute, with a muted tone reflecting the somber atmosphere of the stagnant world, but isn't afraid to splash in some color here and there. The story is good enough, with a cast of characters that is varied, but not especially memorable. The music is utterly fantastic from the main menu onwards, and really elevates the experience overall.

I'd like the fast travel system to be a little more quick (particularly during the "clean-up" phase), but you can always just quit to menu to get to your nearest point if you don't feel like running back. Kudos to the devs for making the collectathon not a chore like it is in some older games. All that said, it's a good deal even at $20. If you can get it on a sale, it's definitely worth it.

130540569.review:
Wonderful indie game. About 10 hours for the end, 15 for 100% completion.

Charming action adventure game that reminds me of the gameplay feel of GBA era Zelda mashed up with the world building of the modern metroidvania / soulslike indie game.
Gameplay was engaging and fun with a difficulty curve that seemed pretty appropriate: just hard enough to make the gameplay a focus but not so hard to distract from the quirky artsy indie vibe
Art and Music were both very solid.
Plot and writing were also very good with a ton of little charm and quirky humor.

Also, for having no map I thought the way secrets were revealed through character dialogue was wonderful and clever. It made tracking down the last few things much easier.

130538832.review:
This was one of those games I started a long time ago, got dunked on, shelved it, then came back when I was stronger. Yeah, I'm glad I came back. This was one of the most fun and enjoyable games I have ever played. Death's Door in my opinion is a Zelda meets Dark Souls blend. The overall gameplay and look give you the cutesy Zelda vibe with its cute graphics and humor. While the story and "feel" of the game will provide you with a Dark Souls feel. 

You play as a crow reaper. You are tasked with taking the soul of a boss monster. Upon defeating it and moments from grabbing the soul, you are knocked unconscious by an older Grey Crow. When you seek him out, you learn that he was also sent on an assignment to collect a soul but it's locked behind a large door. The only way to open the door is to collect these large souls like the one you were about to collect. You must venture out and collect these large souls and open the door. As you journey though, you'll learn there's something bigger going on than you originally planned.

As stated earlier, Death's Door plays like a Zelda/Dark Souls hybrid. The view is isometric and you have a basic dodge roll, attack, and heavy swing. Learning enemy timings and when to attack is important since you only have 4 hit points and it's easy for you to...well...die! You don't get to heal often in this game as you have to find these strange seeds and plant them in flowerpots around the world, that's the only way for you to heal. You have to really get your skills up if you're gonna survive.

The world and exploration of Death's Door is what really drew me to the game. Each area is unique and just like any classic Zelda game, you be revisiting places often when you obtain new weapons and abilities to find secrets. There are collectibles, hidden shrines that raise your health and magic points, and currency. You'll be using soul currency to upgrade your abilities and I found the system very fair and noticed the changes with each upgrade. Deal more damage, increase the speed of your swings, your movement/dodge speed, or the damage of your abilities. You can upgrade your stats however your playstyle demands it (I personally went attack swing then damage build).

The music was very atmospheric and a treat for the ears. I especially enjoyed boss fights in this game as well. Each large soul is held by a boss, and each of them were fun to face off against. Once you figure out their gimmicks, you'll find that they aren't hard to defeat once you get their patterns down. Whenever I lost in this game, I always knew because it was me and not the game. There are hidden endurance rooms too for you to give your abilities passive upgrades as well so exploration and a keen eye is greatly rewarded in this game.

Lastly, I want to point out the great story and characters. While the game doesn't beat the story over your head until the little exposition dump towards the end, you get to meet a lot of characters in the world and it really brings it "life" (heh heh). I found myself really caring about the inhabitants of this world and what they were going through since the rules of death were all wonky because of your boss. What's even better is that once you beat the main story, you gain the ability to change the world to a night cycle and the maps change. More secrets to find, hidden bosses, and a true ending. I did my best to get the hidden ending, but I was just short 3% before I admitted defeat. I still enjoyed it though.

As far as gripes though, I can't really pick many out. I think this game would have benefited from a small minimap, especially when you're trying to find all hidden collectibles to get the 100%. Aside from that, I have no gripes. Every death I had was on me. Even when I dodge rolled off cliffs or into water, I knew that was on me and never felt like the game cheated me.

Final verdict? This was a major treat and great to play. I loved the story, the world, and the gameplay. Some enemies were a pain to fight but that comes with the territory of adventure games like this. The exploration and maps were memorable. Loved one particular boss fight that had me grinning. And I was pushed to go for the 100% even though I gave up towards the end. If you're looking for a Zelda-like game with a good bit of challenge and charm, I highly recommend this game. You can finish it in about 10-15 hours, so it's a pleasant length. Best of luck crow, and remember, death is inevitable for the cycle to flow. Thanks for reading!

130391421.review:
[h1] Bias Review: [/h1] 

Honestly and sadly I wasn't as passionate about this game after finishing it as I expected starting it. I only played one similar game called Hob a year before and I really enjoyed that game so I thought I would have the same experience with Death's Door, I guess I was wrong, I dunno why I wasn't inspired by this game, maybe fallen out of love with this type of generic that quickly (that's possible) or if I needed to take breaks more breaks from it, either way, it's not fair for me to not recommend based fully on my unenergetic experience as generally, this is a good game, just a bit basic for my liking, some of that is due to the combat. I can live with Hob combat being the same way to some extent because that's not the point of that game, it's more so about exploration and solving puzzles, but for Death's Door, I was probably expecting something more in-depth to mix and match buttons. Instead, the combat is just standard and unexciting, like imagine upgrading your firebase ability to be able to.... burn enemies......, I mean I guess, but why couldn't it do that already?

This is down to personal preference I suppose, so that's why I'm constructing this review the way I did, now to unbias review as well as some things I like about this game, so not completing unbias? wait it is possible to make an unbias review even though a lot of media we consumed is subjective, I'm probably thinking too much, am I?

[h1] Unbias Review?[/h1] 

Bias aside, graphically this game is really polished and graphically vagrant to the blocking models and the stunning environment design inviting players to explore, solve some easy puzzles, and find some hidden secrets which are many if you look hard enough. Even if you're an outsider, there's no way you can't give the developer a massive appreciation for the way they implemented a like-dungeon atmosphere you can't help but look around.

Another thing great about this game is that the boss fight felt different from one another with their quirk and messages in the ways they fight. Let's talk about Betty (the yeti) for example, is more so a playfight the way she continually just bounces around and manoeuvre all over the area which makes her unpredictable, but you can understand why because she is just a child who wants to have fun. Or what about The Grey Crow who ends up being a boss-fight, I know surprise, I mean look at his character design, and don't tell me you don't think you'll end up fighting him. But yay, not to get off track, you'll end up fighting him but don't worry it's a good fight to the sorrowful piano chorus, as well as his movement in a sense of desperation and urgency like he has nothing to lose because he lost everything in that moment which I won't spoiler. I just wish we focus on him more beforehand so the reveal can be more impactful, still a good fight by the way he trying to cling to anything to take his anger on.

Another nice touch about the enemies in general now as I like how you can tell how much HP they have a lift by how much they are cracking, for bosses of course they are more durable, which goes to show despite being fragile like glasses they would try everything to their mortal souls intact. Thinking back on that as a metaphor, speak volumes about how many people, animals, or foes we encounter in this game really don't want to die but at the end of the day, death will always be there when it's the right time for them to move on. 

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 

I know I mainly focused on the bossfight in this 'unbias' section, not that everything else about this game wasn't good I just I don't have anything interesting to say about anything else, so don't take it the wrong way. Death's Door is an alright game considering I played something like it before. But if you're new to this sort of game, give it a try and you may enjoy it more than I have.

Recommendation for kids (maybe as a last-minute Christmas or New Year present)- High Recommendation.

Recommendation for people who never played this type of game before- High-mid Recommendation.[/b]

130308467.review:
What a game, what a story.

If imitation is the best form of flattery than this title should make Miyazaki blush.

The games narrative balances solemnity and fatalism with tact and humor. Overall the story provides a great narrative and meditation on the fundamental cycle of all living things and I'm grateful that I played it.

The gameplay itself is good, I would put it closer to an entry title rather than multi inferno Hades run. But I think that actually helps. I never felt it was too easy nor too hard, and the effortful parts felt in service of the story rather than me getting sweaty.

I adore this title. If you like top down actioners, this is for you. If you enjoy Miyazaki-esque titles, this is for you. If you like both you probably already own this.

130302868.review:
Firstly: is it a bad game? No, by all means. I just didn't enjoy it, and to a degree where I don't feel like I can recommend it to others.

Basically, this title has all the makings of a good game, to be one of those atmospheric indie gems I usually love. Graphics, soundtrack, all of that's fine. More than just 'fine', even.

The difficulty itself also isn't a turn-off for me, I'd say I was making progress at a somewhat decent pace at least - thing is, the areas didn't feel challenging to me, they just felt exhausting.
Somewhere between
# long walking distances without a way to speed them up (yet?)
# no map to get a grip of the terrain you're in (I can map things out in my head, but consistently keeping track of them - including spots for backtracking - only adds to the stress)
# a combat system that feels slightly cumbersome (not that it impacts [mini-]boss fights at all, but it doesn't fit the frequent occasions where you face groups of enemies)
# outright annoying camera angles (zooming out for some fights until I completely lost track of the few pixels that make up my character - bad on a big screen, even worse during the session on the Deck)
... my motivation got lost. I tried, because I really wanted to like this game, but I realize that's not going to happen if I have to force myself to continue playing.

As far as I've gotten the story and characters do feel interesting, but there's just too many aspects that didn't sit right with me, turning a charming isometric adventure into a drawn-out marathon.
So, with that said, it's probably an actually great game if you're just here for the story and its characters, or you don't mind running in circles for the umpteenth time.

130176599.review:
Oh, man! That's a tough one. This game has SO MANY good, fantastic things going on. It could've been one of those "must play games" of a "100 games you have to play" or something like that. However... some bad design choices hindered the experience so much.

But before saying the negatives, what are the good things?
First of all, it's a Zelda Like game. You go through dungeons, get stuff to unlock another stuff (won't spoil), each dungeon gives you a secondary weapon that will help you throughout your adventure. 
Combat is simple in a sense that you have your attack, secondary attack (magic), roll and ability to charge your weapon attack.
And you CAN'T simply hack'n slash your way through it (more on that later).

Characters are amazingly charming, the background story seems goofy but it has a lot of depth to it (it's about death, afterall). The style is a mixture of Ghibli, Disney and also it reminded me of some of the 90s point and click games (especially Grim Fandango, which isn't surprising).
I liked the humor also. Nothing over the top. Again, very charming.

So you have a near perfect package. Near ruined by basically two things:

1) Complete lack of a MAP! Being a Zelda-like game, that means the game has a lot of exploration and backtracking.
Although the maps aren't really big (which is good because it's very fast to navigate through them), they are so full of details that it isn't hard to get lost.
The game kinda expects you to know your way by heart after going back and forth...
Well... that does happen eventually, but why? Why not give players a map to make things more smooth?
That's a completely unexcusable fault;

2) The combat and respawn. Like I said, it's relatively simple. Which is great. It kinda goes in a soul-like (or should I say 'soul lite') way. So, if you are not the most skilled player out there (my case) you will have to deal with couple of frustrations: dying and having to go back to where you died, because you respawn at the latest 'check point' (so to speak).
To be fair, older Zelda games are like that. If you died at a boss, you would respawn at the beginning of a dungeon and would have to go your way again till the boss.
But... why? It just makes the things more annoying!

Also, with the lack of a map, not only you have to go back to where you died, but you have to remember the way back there!!
Imagine how frustrating it can be!!

3) Unlike Zelda, you CAN upgrade your stats.... by a bare minimum.
There are four stats that can be increased (Strength, Speed, Dexterity, Magic --basically. They are called something else in the game). Each stat can be upgraded five times by using souls that you collect.
But each upgrade is barely noticeable. Only after upgrading the whole stat you feel A LITTLE difference.


So, in the end, you have this nice package with a very very debatable game play.

I only managed to stay and beat the game because its charm held me there. But those poor design choices really really detracted from the whole experience.

Devs, take note: doesn't matter how pretty your game is, if the actual gameplay isn't fun, then everything else doesn't matter.

In the end I would wish there was a "neutral" rating here. If you are still curious about this game, buy it on a nice sale. It's not worth the full price. Sorry.

129902327.review:
hello all! below i wanna write some thoughts about Death's Door! hopefully it helps anyone on the fence about the game. ENJOY!

[b] things I liked [/b]

- I LOVED the environments! from deep green, vibrant jungles to desolate ice capped mountains, the game invited you to enjoy all the levels with a nice mixture of exploration and secret discovery. There were definitely a few moments I was wowed by the visuals!

- The boss fights were enjoyable as hell! Not only was every boss unique visually, but they all fought in different ways that forced you to always adapt. I was never too frustrated by any unfairness, and once you learned the boss patterns from some trial and error (as this game demands) they became less of a chore and more fun. 

- the storytelling and overall world design were an added bonus for me. I loved finding all the little trinkets that added some flavor text to the world lore, and finding all the odd characters living in the world was something I looked forward to cuz they always offered a little more insight into what was going on, and what happened before. Big props to the writing also, I thoroughly enjoyed it! 

[b] things I didn't like [/b]

- some of the hit detection is wonky and it led to more than a few unnecessary deaths in combat...and sometimes outside of it when I rolled off a bridge or platform LOL. I want to say it isn't a big issue, cuz you learn QUICK to stop making the mistakes. 

- there are some systems in the game, like traversing the underground sewers via those gray disks you find around the levels that weren't explained and a few other little things that coulda used just a little more explanation. Did you know you can deflect almost every attack? Remember that going into this game! 

[b] final thoughts [/b]

I seriously enjoyed the hell out of this game. There was almost no huge problems that made me angry, and I liked the combination of exploration, combat, and storytelling to make for a complete experience. I'm going to highly recommend this game for fans of quirky Zelda-likes. I also enjoyed the Achievement Hunting, I think it had a good mix of exploration and discovery. And one other thing...this is nothing like a Souls-like so please don't let it dissuade you from trying this game.

129554191.review:
Metroidvania, top-down, Zelda-esq that is polished and fun to play. Simplistic, charming, and, enjoyable. Mind blowing that this game was made by only two people, especially when you consider how polished it is, free of bugs, glitches, and crashes. Only if other triple A games with massive budgets and studios 10x the size could do the same these days, but the sad truth now-a-days is that day 1 releases just mean alphas/betas.

When it comes to 100% completing the game, it's not too bad, but I would keep in mind using only the umbrella on a 1st play through for the achievement does make this game a little difficult with a slight learning curve. This game is also a little difficult when it comes to "how to progress." I understand when games, like Dark Souls 1-3, don't out right tell you how to progress with quest markers or maps and hold players hands less. The purpose of those designs in those games are to let the player explore and gain satisfaction when they discover things on their own. However, due to the more metroidvania nature of this game, I feel that some sort of map would have been really helpful. Also, in my opinion, the combat does get a bit stale and repetitive kinda quick once you unlock all weapons and spells, but the beautiful word, unexpectedly deep and philosophical story, and fun bosses are designed well enough to keep you engaged for the whole ride.

Got this as a Christmas gift. Now, I am normally a fan of nice Zelda-like games. But man... this one has some issues.

Pros:
- Great aesthetic
- You play as a little crow
- Octopus chef that manipulates a dead corpse to pretend to be human

Cons:
- Criminally short for what it is - beat it in under 10 hours (if you look at my playtime, I left the game on when family came over for Christmas for a few hours).
- Combat is boring and there's little enemy variety
- Very few upgrades or real benefits for exploration, I beat the whole game and only got 1 health upgrade. Given the game's length there may be about 2 total.
- Very few i-frames on the doge (that becomes important later)
- So much backtracking, no map, and traversal is slow.
- you can fall off edges and your attack sends you forward... I mean, that's a minor point but compounded with everything else...
- There is no way to heal in combat and the boss battles are a slog - they are pattern recognition style boss battles but instead of giving you a free hit after the dodging session you have to wail away at an invisible health bar and repeat the whole thing dozens of times. I almost gave up on the last boss battle since it's long as hell and you can't heal during it.

128834105.review:
[h1]Quality isometric love letter to games like [i]Legend of Zelda[/i] and [i]Little Big Adventure[/i][/h1]

A really wonderful title with plenty of lore. Scratches the [i]Zelda[/i]/Metroidvania itch. Extremely fluid combat, and puzzles with just the right amount of difficulty. This is a spiritual successor to [i]Titan Souls[/i] in many ways and specifically [spoiler]the true ending features common elements which make direct connections[/spoiler]. Purchased on a whim and has easily become one of my favorite games in recent memory.

The only criticisms I can level stem from some control and design choices. I found that the dodge roll often led to my death in close quarters fights one ledges and platforms. The aiming system for projectiles feels cumbersome at first but you get used to it by the end. There is no minimap, which would have been useful in some instances. Lastly, the [spoiler]endgame content is fairly cryptic, with no real tracking of the tablets you need, so if you put the game down and come back later you won't really have a sense of the progress or where you need to go next[/spoiler].

128741306.review:
Bought this game on a whim because I was recommended the song Avarice on Spotify. Did not fail to deliver at all. 

Going into it, I expected it to be another Indie title with a fairly loose story line that didn't really affect much in terms of, I guess, anything, but this game is surprisingly entirely story driven and it's actually a pretty solid narrative, too. I can't really delve into it too much because it's hard to talk about without spoiling anything, but it's good. It's also a secret [spoiler] sequel to Titan Souls, a game developed by this same studio previously. It's not blatantly apparent until you get to the true ending, though. I like it when a game can pull something like that off, even if I've never played Titan Souls to compare things to. [/spoiler]

The gameplay itself doesn't disappoint either. To compare it to a newer title, it's similar in terms of gameplay to Tunic, similar dodge mechanics, same engine, similar difficulty curves, yada yada. So if you've played Tunic then you'll probably enjoy Death's Door as well, and vice versa. That being said, the combat is more varied, you've got a few different weapon choices to better suit your playstyle, and a few ranged skills you can make use of as well. The dungeons and hidden secrets are also really well designed, and without a mini map I often found myself getting lost, which added a lot to the game, imho. 

Then ofc, there's the music. Top fucking notch. Every track is a banger, and I wouldn't even have heard of this game or cared about it if the music hadn't come across my Spotify list and absolutely slapped. 

Overall, good game, it's not expensive so just play it already, what are you doing?

128562762.review:
Why I recommend it? A pretty simple combat, a decent work on locations' style, music/sound, hitboxes that actually work, a consistent general approach to the gameplay -- it is repetitive in a sense, as each world of the main three requires you to look around to 'solve' four smaller parts of it. It might be boring; it had not been boring for me personally.

Backtracking is a thing, and you have no map. With locations pretty big that might be an issue.

But... the game's true ending is kinda awful. Not the ending cinematic which is nice but the road to get there.

This is a metroidvania-lite with three main locations and the hub that has access to all of them. Locations divide into sublocations, each sublocation has a portal leading to it from the hub.

Once you have ended the game, you can switch the time of day. In the night, you now see the glow on the doors that lead into each sublocation. If a door is glowing that means the sublocation has less than 100% of possible collectibles, well, collected. 

At the same time the night adds 7 obscure quests and/or additional collectibles. You need to solve this additional content now, for 7 lights to light up on the true final door. 

Those quests are mostly silent. For the most part you have no NPCs to tell you about them.  You need to interact with them in the wild and see how things change, or notice a pretty obscure object in the faraway dead ends of each location.

I prefer playing without wiki, if I can help it. But this setup is basically "you look at a glowing door wondering what the buck the door wants from you."

On the bright side though the night erases almost all the roaming monsters of the land. At least you can jog through your 15th entry into the labyrinthine locations looking for the Moon knows what in a relative peace.

I'm around 9h in and really into it!  :)

If you liked Titan Souls. You will properly enjoy this one as well. For both games: Well balanced challenges, a beautiful setting and story, well done simple combat, for me straight up 10/10. I was not surprised to find out its from the same developers! Would recommend to people that have experience in (combat) gaming and want something more challenging without having to commit to something as hard/long like  the Dark Souls Games. I enjoy games where you have a simple set of attacks (here: slashing and like for ranged skills) which you have to "master" without a complex skill tree.

I will be following the developers now that I found out they also did Titan Souls :) I'm impressed as how polished and complete this game feels for a team that small. The sound design is also really satisfying to me. 

As some people already mentioned it: This is a relatively "short" experience depending on your skills. This is a quality over quantity game. Don't expect a book full of lore and complexitity because a small team and a game this long can only do that much. 

Honestly, I also think its just different taste of gaming rather than shortcomings by the developers. So please don't give a bad review because it's not your taste. For people who like this type of gaming, it's really a great one! :)

The design of the game is great but the moment you encounter an enemy then you see the holes in it. It has the same dodge roll mechanics as dark souls but sometimes the hit box for an enemy attack is larger than your roll. An upgrade cost 400-1500 points but guess how much a mob gives you on average? Just 2.
