127903594.review:
Death's Door is a gem of a game! Quirky, charming, beautiful, and just the right amount of challenging. It's truly lovely and I highly recommend you play it if it looks like your cup of tea!

I only have a handful of criticisms. First, I wish there had been a map of some kind. It feels like not having one was a deliberate choice by the developers, which I respect. It encourages exploration and immersion into the game's world... but after beating the game, it would've been really helpful while hunting down secrets and could have cut down on the amount of backtracking. This is especially true for The Lost Cemetery region. Most of the regions are pretty straight forward, but even after 17 hours and 100%'ing the game, I still found myself getting lost there!

Also, like I mentioned, there's a lot of backtracking if you're trying to do everything there is. Although, most of the regions are small enough that it's not too much of an issue. There is "fast travel" with the doors, but they're not always close to where you need to go. That said, the doors at the beginning of each region are also the respawn points when you die. Luckily there's usually a door before each difficult section, but not always. This means you might find yourself having to walk from the door back to where you died several times.

Lastly, there's a gameplay mechanic that isn't taught at all during gameplay, and it isn't required to beat the game. However, you do need it for a lot of the secrets. So this meant I had to backtrack needlessly, because I went the entire game expecting to unlock another ability to access those secrets when really the game just dropped the ball letting me know I could already reach them!

Don't let these few small issues deter you from playing it though! It's really fantastic!!

127052366.review:
Finished the postgame. Completionists take note: the central hub highlights which areas still have stuff left to do, so there's no need to manually scour the whole game world. Overall, I'd warn prospective players to expect a lot of mindless bashing of small enemies, but I loved the atmosphere so much it carried me easily through the game. At 16 hours of actual in-game playtime, I really didn't have time to be bored.

I wanted a simple adventure game with a world that I'd be pleased to spend time in, and I got what I came for. DD pares down the formula to its constituent parts - puzzles, tool-based traversal, collecting stuff, simple combat with a selection of enemy types, minibosses, boss-bosses - and creates a straightforward game that does all of that to a degree I would characterize as "solid", where nothing excels, but without too much of any one thing. 

Add in the gorgeous art direction, sweeping OST and charming sound design (special shoutout to [i]Inner Furnace[/i], where the diegetic pumping pistons act as a percussion track for the level music), and you get a game world that is entirely worth spending the 12-16 hours in that it will take to get to the "True Ending".

6.5/10, may or may not play again (if I ever decide to go for the Umbrella achievement)

Edit: Okay, I'm now writing this a few minutes after getting the "100% completion" achievement. I like this game a lot, I had a great time with it. It's not a super long game, I took my time, went back to explore previous areas, and even spent ~30 minutes grinding experience to max out my upgrades before the final boss, and only added up to ~16 hours, so don't go in expecting something the size of Dark Souls, but something that I think is totally worth the money and hours I put into it.

125938714.review:
Incredibly charming and well designed

Each character and boss is unique, funny, and likable.  Each area has a unique feel and easy to learn/understand lore.  The story is easy to understand while not being forced on you.  The music is beautiful and relaxing.

The world lets you speed through or slow down and explore for rewards.  It feels designed to make you feel clever for finding secrets without being obtuse with hiding things.  It provides hints without holding your hand to make completion quick but satisfying.  The abilities use a simple and easy to refill magic system that never leaves you starved for resources and streamlines gameplay.

Boss fights are generally pretty easy but can be challenging for one or two attempts.  Fights are well telegraphed and easy to learn.  Failure means a quick restart and no penalty, so there's minimal frustration.

Overall, if you're looking for a challenge, you probably won't find it here.  If you're looking for a quick and satisfying Legend of Zelda style game, you'll enjoy it and want more.

125793959.review: A beautiful game with a beautiful art style. I'd say that you will probably get 15~ hours of content if you 100% the game. I ended up slower as I'm pretty terrible at it, and I took screenshots of every nook and cranny. The story was serviceable, but the characters made the game for me, as all of them oozed personality. Some parts of the deeper lore don't make sense until put in context, as this game takes place in the same world as Titan Souls. The gameplay circles around 3 main actions (dodging, melee and range), and each gets significantly more complicated and cool as the game goes on, introducing new mechanics and steady upgrades. The puzzles were the weakest part for me, but some of the secret Shinies and Shrines were a joy to figure out (Thank you Jefferson). There's also a pretty dedicated speedrunning community, with some intriguing movement mechanics, glitches and skills to develop, if that's what you're into. All in all, I'd say it was worth it, gave me some giggles and some cheers.

A surprisingly polished game. The one thing Death's Door does best is world design and individual level/area design within that. There was an [b]immense[/b] amount of time, care, and effort put into making sure that the small, plentiful hidden areas both are signposted properly without being too obvious as well as fitting together within the larger world in a way that makes sense. It's truly a testament to the game's world design that throughout the entire course of 100%ing the game, I never felt the urge to resort to a guide. The game expertly straddles that thin line between making discoveries too obvious and properly rewarding the player 
 and making them feel clever. Death's Door just makes sense, and is an extremely polished game (save for a few very small complaints I have about specific enemies) with a lot lurking beneath its surface. You cannot go wrong here.

124844216.review:
A game about the follies of overstaying your welcome that demonstrates its message through experience. A LttP clone featuring charming art that runs twice the length that it has content for. Game play is standard over-world navigation divided into regions with various dungeon dives resulting in boss encounters and equipment collecting to progress.

Puzzle solving is standard fair and combat is incredibly simplistic. Until you get to various bosses, where it remains simplistic but with precision expectations forced on the players, not so much the devs. I-frames and hit boxes will vary per encounter and even animation angle, adding to the tedium that starts to set in about a 3rd of the way through the game. 

There is also an "RPG" leveling system similar to a busy box, but that's overselling it's usefulness. Its so comically vapid that it deserves its own callout. Like, we can move on from these mechanics now. We don't need to have currency and the "+" button next to a list of things we can do or whatever every. single. game.

124752502.review:
Overall, a solid Zelda-like game.  It's not ground breaking in what it does, but it does a few things to make it stand out a bit.  Combat is not super fast, it's meant to be slower and understanding enemy attack patterns.  The combat slows down, with the mechanic of how your character gets stunned each time they take damage and are hit.  This makes combat feel not the best at times.  Also, the games feels unresponsive at times and feels like it could have made more responsive and faster.

The graphics for the game are the biggest negative for me.  The game overall is so solid, that I feel the lack of detail in the graphics hurt the overall game.  If the combat was a bit better and graphics were better with more detail, this game could rate quite a bit higher.  

Positives:

- Neat mixture of melee and ranged combat. 
- Not too difficult, but satisfying combat. 
- Neat secrets where the camera will change perspective for a moment. 
- Simple cute story, not too much dialogue to bog it down. 
- Art style is decent with a neat focus on elevation to make the game stand out a bit. 
- Music stands out as "special". 

Cons:

- Graphics not very detailed.  Game is solid overall and would benefit from better graphics.  
- Customization for your character is not a lot, Only few weapon choices and character spec choices (decent overall). 
- Combat could be faster, more responsive and improved, but can still be satisfying.  At times can feel clunky and unresponsive.  
- Pacing for the overall game is good, but pacing near the end is not very good.  People may grow tired of the game near the end.  This aspect of the game could've been easily modified and fixed.  

Overall solid Zelda-like.  Above average for genre.  One of my favorite Zelda games, but does not stand out as overly special.  Music is strong though.  Combat can be very satisfying, not too difficult.  Melee and ranged combination combat is neat.  There are a few things that could have made this game feel real special.  Although, it's still good. 7/10

124446181.review:
This game is just, one of the best in a long time. It's beautiful to look at, lovely to listen to and so fun to play.

The combat is that perfect level of sort of frustrating (and could the controls be a wee bit tighter? sure, but it's not that bad) but ultimately when you beat the fight it feels _so good_. New spells and weapons are scattered at nice intervals - always popping in right when you've just started mastering the last one. 

I did find the keyboard movement a bit awkward, but it played excellent with a controller.

The music is glorious. All throughout the game it's there, gently pushing you along and keeping you immersed. But when you hit Avarice? Perfection. That track is so well matched to the challenge and just immediately gets you into the groove for the fight. (Am I listening to it right now? There's a good chance :) )

The visuals are so beautiful, and each area is a new level of stunning. Character and boss design is wonderful.

As many others have mentioned, yeah there's no map. But you know, I enjoyed that. Sure, when you get a new ability you have to backtrack without it, but more often than not, I stumbled over a new place or secret because I wasn't blindly following a map back to an exact spot. It encourages exploration, and the level designs are smooth in a way that it's not hard to find your way around. 

There's a lot here that evokes old Zelda games and I am here for it. 

Plus you're a crow with a tiny lightsabre-esque sword? What more do you want?

Overall great game, love the character designs!

123854229.review:
I cannot in good conscience recommend anybody buy this game, which is a real shame because I am a big fan of Titan Souls, as well as the souls-like genre. 

Short version: The game is not as souls-like as I would have preferred, the weapon variety is lacking, and while it started off fun and has some pretty entertaining writing throughout, the game gets extremely repetitive and the boss fights are lackluster and boring, with the exception of the final boss which was just needlessly frustrating.

Before anyone says git gud: I have fought and defeated every boss in every souls game, I am a big fan of the genre and am not one to get frustrated or quit just because an enemy is challenging. 

Long version:

When I began this game I was having a lot of fun, I enjoy the art style, the isometric view, and the fun dialogue. The first dungeon was very entertaining, the environment and enemies were well done, and I realized that I was in for a more Zelda-like affair as opposed to a souls-like. No problem, I like Zelda and again, I was having a lot of fun. 

However, as I continued to play, the flaws of this game started to become more apparent. Every dungeon is the exact same. The enemies vary a little bit but not much, and the way you approach each dungeon is the exact same. You have to go to arenas, kill a certain amount of enemies in order to free 4 trapped souls in each one. After you free the souls, you do a little gauntlet type encounter and get a new power, which you use to explore the rest of the dungeon. That's it. It is literally just walking from one room to another trying to find the room where you fight a bunch of trash mobs. 

A lot of care went into the first dungeon, and so the boring gameplay loop wasn't as apparent, however it is clear that the developers did not spend nearly as much time on the level design of everything past that, which is a shame. 

Now for the part that was the nail in the coffin for me: the bosses were incredibly dull. The art design and the writing on them is solid, however it is a bit uninspired [spoiler] you fight an old lady, a frog, a yeti, and a crow [/spoiler]. The part that makes them bad is the design. Each boss only has about 2 or 3 attacks that they just spam one after the other, so it only takes maybe one or two deaths to learn their patterns and perfectly counter them. The bosses also have about twice as much health as they really should, which turns the game from hack and slash fun to just wait for the boss to do their attacks, and then you hit them a couple times, and then rinse and repeat ad nauseum. This was particularly relevant on the second boss, who literally only had 2 attacks that he did one after the other, and you can only attack him when he's in between them. None of the fights evolve in any significant way. So you've spent an hour slogging through the same enemies through the dungeon just to get a too-long boss fight that you could do with your eyes closed. 

And then....came what I assume is the final boss, I wouldn't know because I could not be bothered to beat him. [spoiler] Referring to the Grey Crow [/spoiler] This boss had the most poorly designed mechanics of any game I have ever played, and again had a frankly ridiculous amount of health. I put all of my upgrade points into strength and melee attack speed, and it is clear that this boss is meant to be killed using ranged attacks. His charge attack just happens, with no warning or visual/audio cue, and if you touch him while he's doing it you take damage. So if you are close to him trying to melee him, he will just get essentially a free hit on you unless you play extremely conservatively. This combined with the aforementioned massive health pool, made this boss fight such an incredible slog that I felt my eyes crossing. That would be bad enough, but he also has a mechanic where every time you hit him a bullet spawns from a completely random point on his body. So you can take damage through absolutely no fault of your own. After the third ten minute slog, I closed the game and do not plan on opening it again.

There is a lot of talent on display here with the art style and writing, its just a shame that the game itself is so incredibly mind-numbing. And honestly, the final boss fight was so bad it made me wish I had gotten to it sooner so that I could request a refund. Do not waste your money on this game.

123841078.review: I generally hate it when people compare games to the Zelda franchise because often times they're nothing of the sort. That being said, Death's Door scratched an itch I've had since beating Okami years ago. I felt so engrossed in the satisfying gameplay loop that I found myself playing the game in every free moment I had. Every dungeon, every puzzle and every character were so spectacularly crafted that I simply want more. This game is not perfect by any means— there were absolutely times where I found myself frusturated having to repeat a fight or an enemy wave because I was just sooooo close to beating it. I don't blame that on the difficulty though, I actually found that part refreshing, but mostly because I had to trek back to the location of the fight. Great games don't have to be perfect though, only feel perfect. I would consider this game a 10/10 in my books.

Death's door is a very great game in indie scale compare to others and it also has so much fun to play. You can either go straight through the game or do some exploration to unlock new things or the true ending. 

Unlike souls series, you will have only 4 health at the start (which can be increase by exploration) with no any kind healing in major fights and every hit you take whatever form bosses or common enemies, It will take same damage as 1 heath. Form the above, this game is quite difficult and you really need to put some time and patience into it.

123658715.review:
[b]"Death's Door" is a small hack n' slash - metroidvania game with some really good elements but obvious faults too. It has artistic aesthetics, peculiar atmosphere, unique npcs, interesting story and offers a lot of exploration opportunities inside its well built world. Yet, for a game of its genre, battles feel slow and not very fluid, kills that your perform don't offer much satisfaction and it generally feels not rewarding as your character never really evolves or strengthen. It's a cool indie game, but it lacks some core elements to make it stand out.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Artistic aesthetics and cute looking, minimalistic 3d visuals with nice chromatic palette.
- Interesting world with peculiar atmosphere, good variation for such a small game and a lot of different places to visit.
- Nice concept and pretty interesting main story with twists.
- Great exploration. There are many hidden collectables, easter eggs and also a hidden finale. The world unlocks gradually revealing new secrets and always giving you extra reasons to explore more.
- Fantastic music. Each region has a different song and most of them are masterpieces.
- Well designed enemies and NPCs with big variation, different attacks and moves. Some of them are really unique. Cool bosses too.
- Smooth animations, bodies that get dismembered, flying particles and convincing overall physics.
- Simplistic yet effective controls. You will get used and master them pretty easily.
- Well balanced. It's easy but with enough challenging moments here and there.
- Clever, discreet sense of humor. 

The bad
- Battles are a little bit slow and not that fluid for a (kind of) hack and slash game. You cannot cancel moves midways and especially that huge roll. You don't feel the heaviness of your weapons or the impact of your hits so kills are not that satisfying.
- There is no run button so it can get a little bit boring when you have to walk long distances. Your character feels slow.
- It is not rewarding at all. You don't feel that you get much stronger of faster no matter how many upgrades you acquire. The gameplay doesn't evolve and you never get the satisfaction that you finally managed to be powerful compared to a weak beginning.
- Puzzles are decent but pretty straight forward like they were designed for children.
- Although it's cute visually, often these graphics felt to me a little bit bulky, especially during cut scenes and close ups.
- These orthographic projection can be frustrating when it comes to perspective understanding like what's higher and what's lower.

123619451.review:
As others have said better than me, this is a beautiful game, the animations are lavish, the environments are evocative. Evocative of what exactly? Well that's the first sign of the problem. This is a shallow experience. 

The story is *there*, but it drags. Captivating stories live inside the head of the reader, they give you something to chew on. When that substance isn't there, other aspects of the experience are magnified, like the time it takes to walk to your next objective, or the rough combat game-feel.

I'm astounded that something this good was made by such a small team, and for what it's worth, I'm still planning to finish this. I feel like this is another victim of playtime-syndrome. I'm haunted by how much tighter this would feel if rather than a 13 hour experience that feels a bit hollow, this was a 4 hour experience where I was left wanting *more*.

123277617.review:
There are many problems with the game but I'd still recommend it for people who love this style of game, whether for the exploration or the souls-like gameplay. Contains some SPOILERS.

The first and most frustrating thing is the slow pace of the game, especially at the beginning before you buy movement speed upgrades, while this game doesn't even have a map, so considering the fact that it has lots of backtracking it can be annoying and then probably you should just follow a guide or even use cheats to increase your movement speed if you want to discover everything yourself. A simple solution would be to have different movement speed during combat, but then again there are many respawning monsters so that could be also a nuisance, so maybe if it would be encounters instead, like in JRPG games, that you enter combat only upon touching monsters. Another thing regarding exploration is the ledges, that you can drop down by accident when trying to do something, whether it is to your death (which at least only damages you) or somewhere on a lower level requiring you to climb back up. Would be nice if you could just teleport between the doors without having to walk between the platforms, since again, it's just wasting time and nothing else...

The second problem for me was the boring combat, it's just button mashing and evading hits/projectiles and if you wish to finish the game with an umbrella for the achievement, it gets even worse, while you can heal only using checkpoints (doors) or the flower pots which have one time use per map reset and you have to hit something, whether pots/crates or enemies to replenish your ranged/magic attacks. So there isn't much choice for combat style. The upgrades don't seem to add too much either so it doesn't feel like there's progress.

The plot is straightforward and easy to follow and even if it may seem bleak, besides the bones of the dead crows (and their spirits) and the bodies of the enemies which remain on the ground, there are barely any scary or disturbing things. Though I don't understand, why can't the crows just fly? Or at least, glide, there's no explanation whatsoever for it.

The puzzles are simple and it's good that there are no real quick time events, besides maybe bull rush or crumbling platforms, but I didn't like the sewer thing, at the beginning I thought you'll need to unlock something in order to open them, like with other things (the ankhs for example), because why would I think right away that you have to jump smash onto them when there are no enemies there?

The art is very nice, it has ragdoll elements and mostly it's obvious what you can do with the various things once you're able, having the endgame content shown to you almost at the very beginning.

The endgame (night) content, which is something like New game+ I guess, is also nice since you are going back to previous areas to explore new content and on the way you can collect items which you missed previously, but again, since you don't know that it will happen, you might be backtracking a lot beforehand to collect those.

123177423.review:
Death's Door is a game that reminds me of how frustrating Steam's rating system is. I appreciate so many aspects of the game, such as the graphics, music, animations, and gameplay, but I'm struggling to find the motivation to complete the game. It is like I'm going around in an aesthetically pleasing world, yet I have no real idea why I should care.

I feel like I ordered a loaded baked potato and got a plate of all the delicious toppings, with no potato. The toppings are still delicious, I just can't help feeling like something is missing.

So not going by my usual review standards, I recommend it because the game has some really good aspects and I'm sure many people will have no issue with completing it. I just can't.

123152238.review:
[h1][b][i]An enjoyable experience with some caveats[/i][/b][/h1]

[u][b]- Story:[/b][/u]


Surprisingly, the story is more prominent that I’d thought. [b]It’s quite fascinating and enjoyable[/b].

The cast are all unique and well designed and thought out, have their own story, and give life and character to this game.

The game seems to shy away from the story at the beginning, but increases irregularly with time, culminating with a crescendo at the end.



[i]Would have liked a more gradual increase or just a constant high level from the start[/i].



[u][b]- Gameplay:[/b][/u]

[list]
[*][b][i]Combat:[/i][/b]

It’s rather simple, but I like it. [b]It emphasizes other aspects of combat[/b] like telegraphing moves, learning attack windows, etc.

One thing of note is, ranged attacks require you to aim beforehand, the aiming animation takes more time than it should, and will not register any shot in the animation. This should be instant. As in you aim and shoot, and not aim, wait and then shoot. This was especially prevalent in a segment of the game where you are required to use the hookshot constantly and consecutively, within short windows. To add to this, most ranged attacks have a wind up. Add both together and you will miss short attack windows in bosses or move before it even registered. Very annoying.

The heavy attack in this game doesn't have an instant and hold variation. Even if you press it, it will act like you're holding and will release after a pre-determined amount of time, not accepting any inputs in the meantime other than a roll, a normal heavy with a hold heavy (like most other games) would have been better and would also flow better and give more agency to the player.

Also, a unified audio and visual cue and a zoom and vibration for both ranged attacks and full holds of the heavy attack and bow would've been nice.




[*][b][i]Puzzles:[/i][/b]


Although puzzles play a more “minor” role when compared with combat, especially early game. I liked what was there, [b]it ranged from adequate, to creative and refreshing[/b].



If I had one gripe with the puzzles it would be similar to the story, [i]it’s an irregular incline that I wish was more stable or regular[/i].





[*][b][i]Exploration:[/i][/b]


Making a hub world is hard. Many games try and fail, and for [b]DD to make one as good as this is an achievement[/b] not every game can have.



Even individual areas are well designed and the dungeons themselves are creative and expressive of the game’s characters.



Unfortunately, the game has no map. [i]It is extremely hard to navigate this intricate and detailed world with no map[/i] when the game requires you to constantly go back and forth.



Sad, as this is my biggest gripe with the game and I see no reason for it.
[/list]




TL;DR: 

Get it if it’s a genre that you like as it is a shining example, and stands shoulder to shoulder with the best of them.

122893168.review:
Death's Door is an absolutely fantastic game that should be played by anyone interested at the very least. Saw some people say the game is short - which it really isn't. With 13 hours I had more than enough fun with the game and it didn't feel like it overstayed it's welcome while still presenting a large variety of things to do. Metroid Dread, a game in a similar fashion (albeit a different genre), took me a lot less time but still had things to explore and didn't overstay it's welcome.

The combat is nothing ground breaking, neither is anything else in the game, it's just pure fun and I never wondered when the end was - I just went ahead with each area, each puzzle, and each boss until it took me to the end. Games that are just simple fun while still having appreciable aspects is what we truly need more of in this industry. I did my fair share of exploring in the game, but even then I still feel like I barely scratched the surface of things to find in it (there isn't an overwhelming amount but still a moderate amount to discover when re-visiting areas with new abilities).

Also, runs really well on the Steam Deck, for those who want to know.

122752896.review: Aspects of this game are pretty good. 122749614.review:
I heard a lot of positives about this game and finally jumped in. All I can say is I wish I played it sooner. The game starts off relatively slow. The combat is very simple yet satisfying. Impacts with your sword feel like they have weight with a dense bassy thud when they impact enemies, immediately making the action fairly addictive. Right off the bat you soak in the music, an amazing mix of violins and flutes that have this dreamlike vibe that carries you through your exploration. The entire soundtrack is amazing and fires you up throughout the game and brings you down during the emotional beats.

Overall visually the game looks stellar. It has a simple, stylized aesthetic, with strong pops of colour making some areas feel lively and other areas feel cold and dilapidated. Designs of enemies can range from really cool and fantastical to almost silly looking, which I personally feel can clash a bit too much.

The gameplay is where I was mostly conflicted. At first the game starts off really simple and slow. Much of the engagement comes from bosses or bigger enemy encounters where you are locked into a room and have to fight through waves. These moments progressively ramped up throughout the game creating some rivetting encounters. Once you acquire new skills the combat takes on a new life. Exploration is also very engaging. I found myself looking around every corner for secrets as the world is densly packed with things to find.

Story wise, it's fairly simple and keeps you pushing through the game. A lot of interesting characters with incredibly well written dialogue. 

8/10

122737422.review:
TRASH.

You should never make another videogame again, because this was clearly a mistake. From bad telegraphing to presumptive non-tutorializing to being far too fucking stingy about upgrade resources and expanding player options, this game offers up no opportunities in its first <2 hours for people to engage with it at their own pace.

Which projectiles are reflectable? Well there are purple and blue ones, and green ones, but not the red ones except sometimes??? How about what I can expect not to be able to shoot through and vise-versa for the enemies? Oh naw only I am affected by certain terrain features which block my shots, meanwhile the guy hiding behind the barrel-with-player-seeking-projectile gets to shoot at me without worry.

Teleporting enemies who can gang-up on you in the boss arena? Check. 
Tedious, confusing, maze like levels with a long and arduous run-back? Check. 
Inability to heal during boss fights? Check. 
Bosses that have 8 hours of attack window and 2 seconds they can be safely attacked? Check. 
An upgrade system that does not offer you any ability to increase your sustainability and mistakes you can make while playing? Check. 
Useless joke weapon at the start and literally no new items or options expanded upon after two boss fights? Check.

How you managed to get the game running smoothly is beyond me, because the basic shit in this game that is incorrect is absolutely balls-on-a-truck-hitch levels of idiotic. Normally I am more polite, but this game infuriated me beyond what should be reasonable because I just had to know how far the inconsistency and bad design rabbithole went. The fact that you really have nowhere to go, no grinding or other "features" of the Dark Souls franchise you so badly want to fellate such that you sabotaged this game's entire design to replicate... it boggles the mind. Not only are you jumping faster than the player on many concepts which the game's cute art style and advertising imply should be more accessible, but you do so badly and without adequately offering up any real fucking options for engagement outside of an extremely fucking basic, and boring, hack slash and roll formula.

I think what pissed me off the most, and what made me almost uninstall the game entirely, was killing a boss and being rewarded 100 upgrade points... after five tries. A quarter of a single upgrade (which mind you barely fucking expands your play options and is completely invisible when applied in such half-steps) of the first tier. It takes 1600 points to get the first blip of each of the four upgrade slots, and they are so limited in their attribute contributions that the level of OBVIOUS FUCKING PADDING that has gone into the stinginess of rewarding you for beating shit is on another fucking level. Again, Dark Souls does this better, and I do not fucking like Dark Souls. When I explored a small section with a SINGLE path I could deviate from the progression route that was accessible to me, I got 100 souls from an orb sitting out in the open with no combat challenge and no puzzle.

What... what the fuck are you doing?! Why is walking into a room as rewarding as beating the second boss in the game??? The boss that took five tries, mind you, was the castle mech which has very janky damage boxing, gets to attack for what feels like hours (roughly 5s to 30s windows it is attacking), and is vulnerable to my attacks without trading hits for less than 2 seconds. It's got a flying phase where its immune to attacks, has a load of health with no health bar (just vague hints of damage based on how cracked its exterior gets), shoots fucking lasers and rockets sometimes AT THE SAME TIME, and can fire those rockets while walking around the map doing it's spinning attack that has really fucking ambiguous telegraphing on where it hits exactly... AND I took damage at one point when I tried to be cheeky and attack it with my sword while it was winding-up its laser attack and had not fired yet, but had no attack animation to hit me with.

This game not only jumps far faster than the player on its difficulty scaling and is bad at communicating reliably what will and will not damage you, when it will damage you, and your window of dodging... but there's an Ornstein looking mother fucker in the second zone full of pot-headed guys who has a tracking lunge attack which has such precise timing that in five attempts I could not dodge it once. That boss has ended my run of this game, because the run back is in an area I can scantly navigate without dragging all of the mobs like it's fucking 2006 and I'm a Bubble-Hearth Paladin in Wailing Caverns in World of Warcraft. Mind you, you have FOUR hits you can take and then you gotta do this shit all over again, and that means yes killing everyone and trying not to take damage so you can enter the boss that will get cheap hits you can barely avoid, and will simply attrition damage you into another attempt.

Padding. Uninspired. Visually deceptive. And that's without talking about the respawning pot puzzle which clearly was designed by someone who wasn't interested in you solving it ambiently as a breather between combat sections. It is not fucking smart to introduce content that players want to try their hand at, and then do it so badly it is plainly unsolvable. No hints, no riddle, nothing, just brute force or look it up, and I decided not to look it up because I wanted to see if the developers of this game could design a basic fucking puzzle. The answer was no, you need a 'special item' to determine the specific arrangement of these 5 random pots out of an arrangement of 13 on a checkerboard 5x5 grid need to be smashed. Oh and your sword arc is too big to precisely smash them if you are standing too close, so you will be confused at first by fucking smashing 8 pots and seeing 5 of them reform, and 3 of them stay broken. When a puzzle resets, the ENTIRE puzzle should reset upon the failed attempt, you amateur hour lead pellet eating neanderthals.

Again and with emphasis: this is basic design shit. Shit that shouldn't be fucking happening in 2022, let alone the year this game was published to steam, things that should be on a goddamn NES cartridge. If you don't want someone to do a puzzle, do not make it fucking accessible, make it something that becomes active due to a teaching moment like those stupid "shoot the arrow through a torch at a blank brazer" puzzles, which frankly I would have never realized was a mechanic if it wasn't explicitly spelled out because I couldn't expect reasonably to know what the idiots who made this game fucking intended with half of the shit on screen.

When four blue mage guys I was trying to run away from teleported into the arena with Ornstein, I quit the game, and I will play maybe a little of the sections I have beaten to record some footage and might assemble one of those youtuber video essays, because the incompetence here is on another fucking level. It is not new for games to be imperfect, nor is it new for people who are bad at a particular game to be mad about it, but it is new to me that someone who could play Dark Souls, base their stupid fucking cute looking bird game on that concept and fuck it up so royally. There was another moment I died in a locked, entirely too long for its section combat arena in the graveyard, and it was because I rolled off a ledge... something that I only understood vaguely could happen in certain areas because until that moment no ledges could be fallen off of into the void in a scenario where it can happen by mistake.

1/10 runs well, looks cute, and plays like shit.

122593647.review:
The game is lacking in providing a good level of feedback and clarity in combat, as well as having no map in a world that's very maze-like. Furthermore the weapon selections is very poor and unimaginative, and buyable "upgrades" for your character are not very noticable and it's hard to get an idea of how much of an improvement they are with no data given.

The game has some challenging encounters and a few interesting enemies, but fails to reward you in an interesting way after the battle.  The narrative is another point that is very under-developed and I often took breaks because there was nothing in the story that pushed me to continue.

The game does offer the occasional interesting level design, but I feel that it still comes up short in the ways it could utilize and exploit it. 
The combat is somewhat good but more needs to be added than simply roll, attack, charged attack, and ranged attack. As these things make it very repetitive, even though it tries to make up for it with diverse enemies to varying success.

Its drive to be simplistic falls to the detriment of making anything feel seasoned and satisfying, and does not tease you to continue the journey for what's around the corner. The game also never gave me a feeling to go back in just to experience the combat, overcome challenges or enjoy any characters one more time.

It's a colorful dish with little flavor.

122554153.review:
I initially gave this game a thumbs down, mainly because of the annoying controls: if you try to move too quickly, the direction you hit in is often opposite to where you were aiming for, causing you to take unneccessary damage and unfair deaths. The character also tends to get stuck behind the tiniest of obstacles. When you start the game your characters moves painfully slowly and his melee weapon has very limited reach. I urge you to quickly work on upgrading your character's abilities because after doing that the game becomes much better playable. Some (mini-)bosses in the early game gave me a hard time, but as I progressed through the game and got new / upgraded abilities, the fights became much easier - perhaps a bit too easy, because several of the late-stage (mini-)bosses I could defeat without taking damage in the first try. This is mainly because many (mini-)bosses not only look alike, their attack patterns are also so much alike that once you know how to beat the first one, the look-a-likes hardly have any surprises left for you anymore.

I bought Death's Door because several reviews described it as Zelda-like. I foolishly expected these reviewers meant BOTW-like, but instead it is more like the old Zelda games, with a heavy focus on dungeon crawling. The game is quite linear in certain  area's, but in other places  you can go off in many directions and really wonder about the place to your heart's content, looking for secrets and other stuff to do. The lack of a map is a bit of a discomfort in the beginning, but on the other hand, the map is devided into several clearly distinct areas that aren't that big so I guess the exploring would become way too easy if a detailed map was available.

I didn't care too much for the story, and the initial and true ending felt a bit underwhelming. The art style is really outstanding, the music and athmosphere are great, and the level design is good too.

122550053.review: Amazing game, with witty writing and superb soundtrack.

122496268.review: Here's the thing. You said a "jackdaw is a crow." Is it in the same family? Yes. No one's arguing that. As someone who is a scientist who studies crows, I am telling you, specifically, in science, no one calls jackdaws crows. If you want to be "specific" like you said, then you shouldn't either. They're not the same thing. If you're saying "crow family" you're referring to the taxonomic grouping of Corvidae, which includes things from nutcrackers to blue jays to ravens. So your reasoning for calling a jackdaw a crow is because random people "call the black ones crows?" Let's get grackles and blackbirds in there, then, too. Also, calling someone a human or an ape? It's not one or the other, that's not how taxonomy works. They're both. A jackdaw is a jackdaw and a member of the crow family. But that's not what you said. You said a jackdaw is a crow, which is not true unless you're okay with calling all members of the crow family crows, which means you'd call blue jays, ravens, and other birds crows, too. Which you said you don't. It's okay to just admit you're wrong, you know?

[h1]Death's Door is a tale about trying to escape an inevitable death.[/h1]

In Death's Door, you play as a reaper crow who's job is to exact that sweet release of life, all while exploring a [b]vast complex of dungeons and elaborately built worlds design[/b]. The game comes with a [b]whimsical soundtrack, and a simplistic, yet eye-catching art style[/b]. The difficulty isn't the most challenging, but still maintains some adversity...  providing a [b]rewarding experience[/b] as you learn to maneuver around new enemies.

I don't much like souls-like games-- for their complex difficulty, but this game hit the sweet spot.

We gather here today to mourn the passing of a great game inspired by many genres...

Zelda-like, Souls-like, Bird-like.

It had excellent gameplay mechanics and a truly lovable cast of characters, as well as potheads...

Some will enjoy it most for its world, combat, music and thought provoking themes about life and death...
While others will only think about Agatha the typist. *shrugs*

But everyone will remember it as an outstanding game.

The last patches have been uploaded and the final bugs have been fixed (or so we hope...) There is no further content to download and no more code to be written.

Bow your head in remembrance. Pay your last respects.

Thank you game devs @ Acid Nerve

(and you too Devolver Digital...)

122301318.review:
I have 10 hours on the game and I hear you can probably 100% it at 15. I feel that is accurate because I'm already near the end but I'm already backtracking to get things I missed. I think I can easily say, if you enjoyed a game like Ori, you will find yourself at home here except with a different perspective. The soundtrack and game play is VERY similar. It has an amazing soundtrack that is relaxing and chill with very  similar Ori vibes and it is basically metroidvania style or in this case, Zelda. You'll start out passing things that you know you should be able to access but cannot yet. At least not until you eventually find the tool or ability needed to do so.

To try to keep this short, I don't think there is much else to say. Graphically is does look really nice and has its moments where you can appreciate the art style. The crow that you play seems rather simplistic and at first I thought it was too cheaply made based on the animation but as I got in further (rather quickly), you'll notice everything comes together perfect. The enemy animations and physics, weapon strikes and attacks are all so fluid and seamless. Even boss fights are enjoyable because of the diversity involved.

I can't say enough good things about this. I had it on my wishlist forever, finally decided to snag it on sale and so glad I did but realize the developers probably deserved more. You can tell this game was created with passion and they put their hearts into it. It really has its own place in all the games I've ever played. Good on you for that. Two thumbs way up.

Personally I thought it was fantastic. The level design, the simple but tough combat, the soundtrack, and the isometric viewpoint all contribute to making this one of my favourite games of 2021.

I cannot overstate how brilliant I thought the level design was. The plentiful shortcuts make backtracking simple while the elements you see while still lacking means to interact with them tell you that you have plenty of reason to come back and explore the area later. I also liked the lack of a map. There was no constantly stopping to pull up a map, or looking at a minimap the whole time. You just explore and memorise. It was a nice change of pace.

i love this game! i really do-- from the storytelling (at the current point im at) to the music, graphics and all, it all feels really nice at times! i adore the characters, especially our protagonist; their cutscenes here and there are really cute! but uh.. 

..at times, in my short span that i've played this game, i have found a couple of problems here and there 
movement feels super slow, and that REALLY sucks considering if you die you have to trek through a large and confusing level ALL over again. even rolling cant save it from what i figured out
and again, maps are confusing to navigate at times, and it doesnt help that you dont exactly have a guide or any sort of, well, map to help you out 

when you die it feels absolutely HORRIBLE to have to find yourself back at the door, trying to run past respawned enemies you dont want to deal with in a confusing environment; even the shortcuts dont save you

combat also feels weirdly clunky at times-- i can see myself barely using the charged attacks to mix up the combat or even so much as deal more damage, spells dont go off sometimes even if i charged them fully, and sometimes when it feels like i shouldve hit an attack (or shouldnt have gotten hit because i know for certain i dodged), it doesnt register 

perhaps its a skill issue though
all in all though, still, it's a wonderful game dont get me wrong
but some aspects are just not for me i guess

in short, i absolutely adore this game, but due to some aspects that just irk me, i just cant recommend it as wholeheartedly as i want to
(but that doesnt mean im not 100%ing the game)

122157772.review:
Death's Door felt pretty average. Okay soundtrack, I liked it, but none really stick with me or stand out. The main theme of the grey office level I can kinda remember because you hear it the most, but even that isn't too memorable. The visuals are great! I like the aesthetic but it's not too unique either in my opinion. Some of the animations before the chest boss fight are kinda cute.

My main issue with the game is the controls feel inconsistent, movement is very slow, levels are hard to navigate, the enemies and hit boxes/stagger feel strange, and the upgrades don't really matter. The movement when 90% of the game is walking should feel good, but it's just so terribly slow in these large levels, even with the roll. There is no use of the crow flying, or even gliding, which would have been more interesting. Especially after dying, you have to trek through half the level doing the same fight over. It's just kinda boring having to walk/roll half the game, and the speed upgrade doesn't do much unless you max it out. The levels are giant, which is cool! But without a map, they're very difficult to navigate back to something you found earlier because it all looks the same after awhile in the level.

The enemies and hit boxes also feel really inconsistent, as do some of the spell timings and how they aim. Sometimes it feels like there's an auto aim that actually makes you miss your target, or sometimes it charges but doesn't go off. The rolls/dodges also were very inconsistent, sometimes being hit in the middle of what I think is the immunity frame. I understand getting hit before the immunity frame, or after, but sometimes I'd get hit when I dodged and timed it right (although, there may be no immunity/dodge, but then what is the point?). 

Also, for the amount of soul the upgrades cost, they do practically nothing. It's not very visible in game, I upgraded the strength 3x and most enemies still took the same amount of hits as without an upgrade. The magic one is probably the best, I felt that it's upgrades were slightly more visible (but I also collected the power ups by defeating the minibosses, so I'm not sure if it was the upgrades or powerups that made it stronger).

The story was the worst. Pretty lackluster, and just pretty boring. It was pretty predictable who the big bad was, there weren't much plot twists. The lore or backstory to the game feels pretty tacked together, and the story isn't really cohesive. The logic of the bad guy didn't make sense. I get not wanting to die, trust me, but with how the world is built he can't do much about it, so there's not really any reason to do all the stuff he did. It also still doesn't make sense why he did any of the stuff like closing the doors if our character was still able to use/open them? If he was trying to isolate the crows so they wouldn't reap him? Idk, he let them stay in business and use his doors and is then killed by letting them do that. When previously he locked all of the doors, but now he's letting them be used again? Idk. I know I'm thinking too much about it but dang, I didn't really enjoy the game or the controls, or the story. I only enjoyed the graphics, but so many games have good graphics it doesn't mean much. Especially if the gameplay feels as inconsistent. I was excited to play but pretty let down.

121966214.review:
TLDR;
[list]
[*] Story: 9/10 - Grim but comically grim.
[*] Combat: 8.5/10 - Gets quite repetitive but feels solid.
[*] Gameplay: 8.5/10 - Your life bar is precious and healing points is sparse. Little to no grind is required.
[*] Art Style: 9/10 - Vibrant and awesome boss designs.
[*] Music: 9.5/10 - Eargasm
[/list]
If you got that craving for a Zelda-like gameplay then this might satisfy you. Finished the game to 100% and unlocked the [spoiler] true ending achievement (which is question marked here in steam) [/spoiler] in 18 hours. Maybe around 6-7 hours was spent to backtrack so that I wouldn't miss a thing. Combat is solid. You get a few selection of fun weapons and magic to aid you. No grinding is needed that much to finish the game but if you want to maximize your skills, you need to allot extra time for it. Story is very interesting. You're a crow, who is hired to be a reaper. [spoiler] You're task with a soul to reap but after slaying that enemy, the soul was stolen from you by another reaper who is very old to open Death's Door but it wasn't enough. So he then tasks you to reap 3 stronger souls to open the door. But it gets deeper than that. There's bureaucracy, there's hidden agendas, and secret societies that I won't get into detail. [/spoiler] There's a lot more than this so you just have to play the game to experience it and I highly recommend playing it. The art style is beautiful and the environment and level design is quite small but very dense. Music is also one of the best tracks and fits well in every level of the game. Highly recommended.

Nice little (pretty short) game with plenty of rather diverse bosses. The bosses are generally pretty easy but still fun. There's a bunch of collectibles that you'll stumble across more or less naturally just while playing regularly if you keep your eyes open and a lot of secrets to discover. The NPCs are generally well done and the game manages to be funny without being overly silly.
The only really big downside is imo the lack of a more extensive fast-travel system since currently you'll be running along the same routes over and over again without any actual gameplay happening along the way. Some minor gripes: the endgame wasn't entirely clear to me (i.e. I assumed you had to do things in a specific order, which is not the case: there is no missable content) and I banged my head against some puzzles for quite a while that aren't solveable until the very end of the game which was kind of a bummer. In general it's definitely recommendable though.

121857160.review:
Previously en Manqueando... "Lost Ruins", que no estaba nada mal. De hecho, estaba bastante bien.
Y en el episodio de hoy de Manqueando... "Death's Door"

De "párajos" va la cosa. Encarnamos a un cuervo que tiene que recolectar un alma. Pero todo se complica y... hasta aqui puedo leer. No voy a spoilear nada, tan sólo diré que la historia está bastante bien y que pese al aspecto del juego, no es para nada infantil. Eso es bien.

Pero... ¿que es esto? Pues un metroid con perspectiva isométrica y gráficos simples pero muy vistosos. Técnicamente bastante bien en todos sus aspectos. Ni bugs ni gaitas, que yo me haya encontrado al menos.

La jugabilidad... pues más o menos como en un Diablo, principalmente por la perspectiva, pero no tiene nada que ver con el mismo. Tenemos posibilidad de golpear, cargar ataque, usar habilidades secundarias, rodar para evitar daño... ese tipo de cosas.

La dificultad es el punto más... llamativo. Es alta, pero básicamente porque no tenemos curación. Y me explico...

A lo largo del juego, iremos encontrando unas semillas que podremos plantar en unas macetas que tambien iremos encontrando. Si las plantamos, podremos usar las flores resultantes para curarnos 1 vez. Hay varias de estas por cada escenario, pero solo si plantamos semilla podremos usarlas. Algo que le da al tema un cierto toque estratégico, ya que nos obligará a elegir donde plantar dichas semillas. Se rellenan si regresamos al lugar tras haber ido a la "oficina".

Sin embargo, cuando lleguemos a un enfrentamiento con un boss, no tendremos curación de ningun tipo, lo que hará que durante ese tipo de enfrentamientos (o en salas cerradas con oleadas de enemigos), la dificultad se dispare un poco. Pero si yo he podido... ¡vosotros podeis!

Y bueno... no sé que más puedo añadir. Buen control, dificultad tirando a alta sobre todo en bosses, buena música y apartado técnico, unas 15/20h para pillarlo todo (13h me ha llevado sacar un 89%), asi que en general todo bastante bien.

Ah si... se me olvidaba. NO HAY MAPA. Eso es un kgadón importante, sobretodo para el backtracking.

Pero pese a ello... lo recomiendo y le voy a cascar un pedazo de 8 como un sol.

Y en el próximo episodio de Manqueando... no clue yet. Stay tuned for new updates!

121682159.review:
This game is exceedingly boring. It has a nice and clean visual presentation, but the gameplay beneath holds no depth or engaging experiences. 

Combat is one note. You swing, you roll and have a projectile you need to charge and that's about it. It's very easy, but it is more a test of patience than anything. There's also a subset of attacks you can't even really react to, you just have to keep moving to dodge everything and poke enemies to whittle down their health.

There is an attempt at some combat variety. Different weapons, they all look different, which is nice. However their impact on game-play is almost unnoticeable. Some swing faster, a bit wider etc. All moving knobs of damage, speed etc. But in the end they all feel the same. You can also upgrade your character and these are similarly boring and barely noticeable. Move slightly faster, deal slightly more damage, swing slightly faster etc. What game really lacks is unique abilities, interesting weapons, or even enemies. A small nitpick, the presentation of the game is very smooth and clean. But the combat animations are woeful. There's almost zero attack animation, your weapon teleports back onto your character. It immediately stuck out like a sore thumb to me the very first time I swung my sword. This isn't earth shattering, but is an odd drop in quality compared to the rest of the games presentation.

The games main emphasis seems to be on its combat. There are some puzzles. However they are also very boring. Simple push the switch puzzles, light X torches etc. Utterly lacking in creativity or difficulty. 

This game also has a lot of walking. I even tried to max upgrade my speed ASAP just to minimise this backtracking. It is hurt very much by the lack of a map. The lack of a map is not an inherently bad thing, however you need to make your areas distinctive. There's clearly been some attention to this and some areas are like this, but others aren't. It becomes more problematic in places such as the forest, where everything just feels like rock, grass and elevated terrain. I'd spend a lot of time just finding the next place to go.

One thing the game does have going for it, is its atmosphere. The game is very calming, music very mellow, very chill. With its mostly clean presentation, it certainly looks polished on the surface.

I haven't beaten the game, so can't comment on the story in its totality. However, it doesn't seem to be anything special after completing the 2nd dungeon.

Overall, if you're looking for something with interesting game play or puzzles, you won't find that here. If you don't care about the game play, and just want to listen to some mellow tunes in a well presented package, you may get something out of this (and maybe the story picks up?).

Yes, you can stay at the center but not all types of enemies cut the distance to you, some run away.
* For Most of the game you will be allowed to recharge your... "shooting weapon". But on most closed arenas with few waves of enemies -- for some reason not. You have to fight them the way designers decided or close the game.

Overall, trying to formulate a short conclusion I can only say the next: cool game but lacks difficulty settings. For me personally it's a bit "too much" so I had to jump to PC (from Deck) and find a trainer.

121342799.review:
Death's Door is a very fun game, filled with charm and polish. The game understands how to make its set pieces grand as well and the bosses are very fun to beat. After you beat the game there will be quite a bit of stuff to still do that does a good job making 100% this game quite a bit of fun. Some time ago I played and reviewed Titan Souls (Acid Nerve's other game) and complained about the constant down time after death to refight bosses that killed you, fortunately Death's Door does a great job, not just in companion with alleviating this issue, doing a great job reducing the down time that you might expedience.

Overall a great game to try out, 100% completion time is about 12-15 hours with the main game seeming to be done in about 10ish. My only gripe is the lack of a way to re-fight bosses without starting a new game (something that is a bit more annoying as there are 2 achievements that are about doing something specific to specific bosses). These are not required to 100% the game, along with the beating the game with the worst weapon achievement but it still is a small annoyance. Especially as the bosses were fun to fight, and even without the boss specific achievements refighting some of them on my completed save would be fun.

Despite all of that Death’s Door is well worth the 20 USD price tag, and I would say even buying this at a low discount makes it a must buy, especially if the game seems interesting to you.

121325342.review:
Absolutely great game! 

Death's Door is so solid y'all. Gives me the old school lock & key vibe of 2D zelda's, but replaces puzzles with combat challenges and an even heavier reliance on exploration. The combat itself is, at times, a puzzle though. You're given a pretty solid move pool from the jump and the challenge comes with surviving these battles without the ability to heal during them. Very little room for error, but the penalty for failure wasn't steep. So it kept me coming back for more. By the end of the game, I was dancing around enemies. It was a good reward for mastering the movement and skills of my little crow friend.

You may wonder if being purely combat focused hurts the best part of zelda, the puzzles. I'd say no because the world is so rich with secrets and things to discover that it scratches the same itch. At least for me. There's no map in this game, like at all. I was originally weary about this discovery, but I started to be more observant. This game rewards you consistently for that, so I began to admire this choice. So yeah, expect to get lost at first. But it's part of the charm.

And the charm is what hooked me. This is one of those lore-based games akin to games like Dark Souls or Hollow Knight, with much of world-building delivered from searching for it. Death's Door does have a more direct narrative however. It tells the story it wants to tell in a nice way, and while the themes of death lean toward the melancholy, It knows when to bring in the levity to avoid being a downer. Don't be fooled, this game has a sense of humor.

The soundtrack is excellent too. I found myself humming the main theme a lot, as it's used throughout but changed to fit certain moments and fights. I'm not musically inclined, but the best way to describe it vibe-wise, is that it sounds sad but hopeful. Bittersweet? A good example is the music that plays when you defeat a major boss. The melody that plays, after you defeat them and a certain character says their piece about the fight, is beautiful. 

If asked what I didn't like, I'd probably say it gets a little grindy at the end. I got "100%" completion before getting all the upgrades because enemies give very little of the game's currency. Thankfully you don't NEED to be maxed out stat-wise. Most of the improvements are so gradual, that you really don't notice them anyway. Plus, I think I liked the fact that I took on a lot of fights without full power because it made those fights even tougher. What happened a lot for me was defeating a boss with 1hp left and feeling like a goddamn survivor. 

Ah well I just ended up praising it again. Listen, this game is dope. Give it a shot sometime and you hopefully won't regret it.

-Fun writing and characters

121085706.review:
Incredible game, simple but fun challenging combat, endearing characters, nice minimalist story, great sense of humour, fantastic music, cute visuals. 

Handles game balance very well with meaningful choices, though it's somewhat limited.

Puzzle design is really smart and well-telegraphed, with many tricky but clever secrets with fun solutions.

I loved the music to the point where I actively found myself humming along with the melodies. Very expressive, with a ton of character. Really brings the game to life.

Backtracking is somewhat overbearing. I tend to dislike being able to see things that I cannot collect, where the only obstacle is something that can be removed without any real engagement by an upgrade. Also don't appreciate having multiple different upgrades necessary to collect all of the items from a previous area, since it encourages more backtracking than should be necessary. Ideally, such things should be relegated entirely to more oft-visited areas, such as the game's various hub areas. Also, they don't ever express that you have a ground pound, despite it being needed for secrets across the full expanse of the game, leading to you needing to needlessly backtrack even more.

Still a little buggy, but nothing game-breaking.

Ultimately strongly recommended. The positives greatly outweigh any of my gripes, though I hope said gripes are addressed in future games.

120940796.review:
Coming off the back of Ori: The Blind Forest, I was immediately struck by the similarities between the two games. Clean, responsive controls, and evolving enemies make sure you're always alert. A death never feels like being cheated, and the punishment for dying is generally just about enough to keep you trying without being too disappointed.  The game length keeps things from getting too samey.

The only drawback is the lack of a map. I think this discourages exploration for secrets, since you can easily wind up going in circles.

Liked:  
- Variety of enemies, teaching you something as they got harder without being unfair
- Interesting and confident aesthetic and story
- Secrets with significant ability boosts that reward exploration

Disliked:  
- High-ground/low ground levels with dead ends that don't intersect and no master map to orient yourself.
- Some level-ups felt underwhelming / unnoticeable
- No map discourages backtracking to find all the cool stuff.
